div.p: THE ASSIGNATION: OR, Love in a Nunnery. As it is ACTED, At the THEATRE-ROYAL.
Written by IOHN DRYDEN Servant to His MAJESTY.
LONDON: Printed by T. N. for Henry Herringman, and are to be sold at the Anchor in the Lower Walk of the New Exchange. 1673.

div.head: TO MY MOST HONOUR'D FRIEND Sir CHARLES SEDLEY, Baronet.
div.p:
THe Design of Dedicating Playes, is as common and unjust, as that of desiring Seconds in a Duel. 'Tis engaging our Friends (it may be) in a senceless quarrel, where they have much to venture, without any concernment of their own. I have declar'd thus much before-hand, to prevent you from suspicion, that I intend to interest either your judgment or your kindness, in defending the Errours of this Comedy. It succeeded ill in the representation, against the opinion of many the best Judges of our Age, to whom you know I read it e're it was presented publickly. Whether the fault was in the Play it self, or in the lameness of the Action, or in the number of its Enemies, who came resolv'd to damn it for the Title, I
will not now dispute: that wou'd be too like the little satisfaction which an unlucky Gamester finds in the relation of every cast by which he came to lose his Money. I have had formerly so much success, that the miscarriage of this Play was onely my giving fortune her revenge: I ow'd it her; and she was indulgent that she exacted not the paiment long before. I will therefore deal more reasonably with you, than any Poet has ever done with any Patron: I do not so much as oblige you for my sake to pass two ill houres in reading of my Play. Think, if you please, that this Dedication is onely an occasion I have taken to do my self the greatest honour imaginable with Posterity; that is, to be recorded in the number of those Men whom you have favour'd with your Friendship and esteem. For, I am well assur'd, that besides the present satisfaction I have, it will gain me the greatest part of my reputation with after-Ages, when they shall find me valuing my self on your kindness to me: I may have reason to suspect my own credit with them, but I have none to doubt of yours. And they who perhaps wou'd forget me in my Poems, wou'd remember me in this Epistle.

This was the course which has formerly been practis'd by the Poets of that Nation who were Masters of the Universe. Horace and Ovid, who had little reason to distrust their Immortality; yet took occasion to speak with honour of Virgil, Varius, Tibullus, and Propertius their Contemporaries: as if they sought in the
testimony of their Friendship a farther evidence of their fame. For my own part, I, who am the least amongst the Poets, have yet the fortune to be honour'd with the best Patron, and the best Friend. For, (to omit some Great Persons of our Court, to whom I am many wayes oblig'd, and who have taken care of me, even amidst the Exigencies of a War,) I can make my boast to have found a better Maecenas in the person of my Lord Treasurer Clifford, and a more Elegant Tibullus in that of Sir Charles Sedley. I have chosen that Poet to whom I would resemble you, not onely because I think him at least equal, if not superiour to Ovid in his Elegies: nor because of his quality for he was (you know) a Roman Knight as well as Ovid: but for his Candour, his Wealth, his way of Living, and particularly because of this testimony which is given him by Horace, which I have a thousand times in my mind apply'd to you.
Non tu Corpus eras sine pectore; Dii tibi formam,
Dii tibi divitias dederant, artemque fruendi.
Quid voveat dulci Nutricula majus Alumno
Quam sapere, & fari possit quae sentiat, & cui
Gratia, forma, valetudo contingat abunde;
Et mundus victus, non deficiente crumena? Certainly the Poets of that Age enjoy'd much happiness in the Conversation and Friendship of one another. They imitated the best way of Living, which was to pursue an innocent and inoffensive Pleasure; that which one of the Ancients called Eruditam voluptatem.
We have, like them, our Genial Nights; where our discourse is neither too serious, nor too light; but alwayes pleasant, and for the most part instructive: the raillery neither too sharp upon the present, nor too censorious on the absent; and the Cups onely such as will raise the Conversation of the Night, without disturbing the business of the Morrow. And thus far not only the Philosophers, but the Fathers of the Church have gone, without lessening their Reputation of good Manners, or of Piety. For this reason I have often Laugh'd at the ignorant and ridiculous Descriptions which some Pedants have given of the Wits (as they are pleas'd to call them:) which are a Generation of Men as unknown to them, as the People of Tartary or the terra Australis are to us. And therefore as we draw Giants and Anthropophagi in those vacances of our Maps, where we have not Travell'd to discover better; so those wretches Paint leudness, Atheism, Folly, ill-Reasoning, and all manner of Extravagances amongst us for want of understanding what we are. Oftentimes it so falls out, that they have a particular picque to some one amongst us; and then they immediately interest Heaven in their quarrel: As 'tis an usual trick in Courts; when one designs the ruine of his Enemy, to disguise his malice with some concernment of the Kings: and to revenge his own cause, with pretence of vindicating the Honour of his Master. Such Wits as they describe, I have never been so unfortunate to meet in your Company:
but have often heard much better Reasoning at your Table, than I have encounter'd in their Books. The Wits they describe, are the Fops we banish: for Blasphemy and Atheism, if they were neither Sin nor Ill Manners, are Subjects so very common, and worn so Thredbare, that people who have sence avoid them, for fear of being suspected to have none. It calls the good Name of their Wit in question, as it does the Credit of a Citizen when his Shop is fill'd with Trumperies, and Painted Titles in stead of Wares: we conclude them Bancrupt to all manner of understanding: and, that to use Blasphemy, is a kind of applying Pigeons to the Soles of the Feet: it proclaims their Fancy as well as judgment, to be in a desperate condition. I am sure for your own particular, if any of these Judges had once the happiness to converse with you, to hear the Candour of your Opinions; how freely you commend that wit in others, of which you have so large a Portion your self; how unapt you are to be censorious; with how much easiness you speak so many things, and those so Pointed, that no other Man is able to excell, or perhaps to reach by Study; they wou'd, in stead of your Accusers, become your Proselites. They wou'd reverence so much good Sence, and so much good Nature in the same person: and come, like the Satyre, to warm themselves at that Fire, of which they were ignorantly afraid, when they stood at distance. But, you have too great a Reputation to be wholly free from Censure: 'tis a fine which Fortune sets upon all extraordinary
persons, and from which you should not wish to be deliver'd till you are dead. I have been, us'd by my Critiques much more severely, and have more reason to complain, because I am deeper tax'd for a less Estate. I am ridiculously enough accus'd to be a contemner of Universities, that is in other words, an Enemy of Learning: without the Foundation of which I am sure no Man can pretend to be a Poet. And if this be not enough, I am made a Detractor from my Predecessors, whom I confess to have been my Masters in the Art. But this latter was the accusation of the best Judge, and almost the best Poet in the Latine Tongue. You find Horace complaining, that for taxing some Verses in Lucilius, he himself was blam'd by others, though his Design was no other than mine now, to improve the Knowledge of Poetry: and it was no defence to him, amongst his Enemies, any more than it is for me, that he Prais'd Lucilius where he deserv'd it; PaginÃ¢ laudatur eÃ¢dem. 'Tis for this reason I will be no more mistaken for my good meaning: I know I honour Ben Iohnson more than my little Critiques, because without vanity I may own, I understand him better. As for the Errors they pretend to find in me, I could easily show them that the greatest part of them are Beauties: and for the rest, I could recriminate upon the best Poets of our Nation, if I could resolve to accuse another of little faults, whom at the same time I admire for greater Excellencies. But I have neither concernment enough upon me to write any thing in my own Defence, neither
will I gratifie the ambition of two wretched Scriblers, who desire nothing more than to be Answer'd. I have not wanted Friends, even amongst Strangers, who have defended me more strongly, than my contemptible Pedant cou'd attacque me. For the other: he is onely like Fungoso in the Play, who follows the Fashion at a distance, and adores the Fastidius Brisk of Oxford. You can bear me witness, that I have not consideration enough for either of them to be angry: Let Maevius and Bavius admire each other, I wish to be hated by them and their Fellows, by the same reason for which I desire to be lov'd by you. And I leave it to the world, whether their judgment of my Poetry ought to be preferr'd to yours; though they are as much prejudic'd by their Malice, as I desire you should be led by your Kindness, to be partial to, Sir,

closer.signed: Your most Humble and most Faithful Servant John Dryden.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: PRologues, like Bells to Churches, toul you in
With Chimeing Verse; till the dull Playes begin:
With this sad difference though, of Pit and Pue;
You damn the Poet, but the Priest damns you.
But Priests can treat you at your own expence:
And, gravely, call you Fooles, without offence.
Poets, poor Devils, have ne'r your Folly shown
But, to their cost, you prov'd it was their own.
For, when a Fop's presented on the Stage,
Straight all the Coxcombs in the Town ingage:
For his deliverance, and revenge they joyn:
And grunt, like Hogs, about their Captive Swine.
Your Poets daily split upon this shelfe:
You must have Fooles, yet none will have himself.
Or, if in kindness, you that leave would give,
No man could write you at that rate you live:
For some of you grow Fops with so much haste,
Riot in nonsence, and commit such waste,
'Twould Ruine Poets should they spend so fast.
He who made this, observ'd what Farces hit,
And durst not disoblige you now with wit.
But, Gentlemen, you overdo the Mode:
You must have Fooles out of the common Rode.
Th' unnatural strain'd Buffoon is onely taking:
No Fop can please you now of Gods own making.
Pardon our Poet if he speaks his Mind,
You come to Plays with your own Follies lin'd:
Small Fooles fall on you, like small showers, in vain:
Your own oyl'd Coates keep out all common raine.
You must have Mamamouchi, such a Fop
As would appear a Monster in a Shop:
Hee'l fill your Pit and Boxes to the brim,
Where, Ram'd in Crowds, you see your selves in him.
Sure there's some spell our Poet never knew,
In hullibabilah da, and Chu, chu, chu.
But Marabarah sahem most did touch you,
That is: Oh how we love the Mamamouchi!
Grimace and habit sent you pleas'd away:
You damn'd the Poet, and cry'd up the Play.
This thought had made our Author more uneasie,
But that he hopes I'm Fool enough to please ye:
But here's my griefe; though Nature joyn'd with art,
Have cut me out to act a Fooling Part;
Yet, to your praise, the few wits here will say,
'Twas imitating you taught Haynes to Play.

div.head: THE ASSIGNATION: OR, Love in a Nunnery.
div.stage: SCENE ROME. A Great Glass Plac'd.
Enter Benito, with a Guittar in his hand.

sp.speaker: Benito
sp.p: bowing to the Glass. SAve you, sweet Signior Benito; by my faith I am glad to see you look so bonily to day: Gad, Sir, every thing becomes you to a miracle! your Perruke, your Cloaths, your Hat, your Shoo-tyes; and, Gad, Sir, let me tell you, you become every thing; you walk with such a grace, and you bow so pliantlyâ€”

sp.speaker: Aurelian
sp.p: within. Benito, Where are you, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Sirrah! That my damn'd Master should call a man of my extraordinary indowments, Sirrah! A man of my indowments? Gad, I ask my own pardon, I mean, a person of my indowments; for a man of my parts and tallents, though he be but a Valet de Chambre, is a person; and, let me tell my Masterâ€” Gad, I frown too, as like a person as any Jack-Gentleman of'em all; but, Gad, when I do not frown, I am an absolute beauty: whatever this Class sayes to the contrary: and, if this
Glass deny it, 'tis a base, lying Glass, so I'll tell it to its face, and kick it down into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Aurelia
sp.p: within. Why Benito, How long shall we stay for you?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I come, Sir. What the Devil would he have? But, by his favour, I'll first survey my Dancing, and my Singing. He playes on the Guittar, and Dances and Sings to the Glass. I think that was not amiss: I think so. Gad, I can Layes down the Guittar. Dance, and play no longer, I am in such a rapture with my self. What a villanous base fate have I? with all these excellencies, and a profound wit, and yet to be a Serving-man!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why, you Slave, you Dog, you Son of twenty Fathers, am I to be serv'd at this rate eternally? A pox o'your conceited coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Camillo.
sp.p: Nay, prythee, Aurelian, be not angry.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You do not know this Rogue, as I do, Camillo. Now, by this Guittar, and that great looking-glass, I am certain how he has spent his time. He courts himself every morning in that Glass, at least an hour: there admires his own person, and his parts, and studies postures and grimaces, to make himself yet more ridiculous, than he was born to be.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: You wrong him sure.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I do; for he is yet more fool than I can speak him: I never sent him on a message, but he runs first to that Glass, to practice how he may become his errand. Speak, Is this a lye, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I confess, I have some kindness for the mirrour.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: The mirrour! there's a touch of his Poetry too, he could not call it a Glass. Then the Rogue has the impudence to make Sonnets, as he calls 'em; and, which is a greater impudence, he sings 'em too: there's not a Street in all Rome which he does not nightly disquiet with his villanous Serenades: with that Guittar there, the younger brother of a Cittern, he frights away the Watch; and for his Violin, it squeaks so lewdly, that Sir Tibert in the gutter mistakes him for his Mistriss. 'Tis a meer Cat-call.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Is this true Benito?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: to Cam. aside. My Master, Sir, may say his pleasure; I divert my self sometimes with hearing him: Alass, good Gentleman, 'tis not given to all persons to penetrate into Mens parts and qualities; but I look on you, Sir, as a man of judgment, and therefore you shall hear me play and sing.

div.stage: He takes up the Guittar and begins.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why, you invincible Sot you, will nothing mend you? Lay't down, orâ€”

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: to Camillo. Do ye see, Sir, this Enemy to the Muses? he will not let me hold forth to you. Layes down the Guittar. O Envy, and Ignorance, Whither will you!â€” But, Gad, before I'll suffer my parts to be kept in obscurityâ€”

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What will you do, Rascal?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I'll take up the Guittar, and suffer heroically.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What? Do you Mutiny?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ay, do, kick till your toes ake; I'll be baffled in my Musick by ne'r a foot in Christendome.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I'll put you out of your time, with a vengeance to you.

div.stage: As Aurelian kicks harder, Benito sings faster, and sometimes cryes out.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: holding Aur. Nay, then 'tis time to stickle. Hold, Aurelian, prythee spare Benito, you know we have occasion for him.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I think that was well kick'd.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: And I think that was well Sung too.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Enough, Aurelian.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: No, Sir; let him proceed to discourage vertue, and see what will come on't.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Now to our business: but we must first instruct Benito.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Be rul'd by me, and do not trust him: I prophesie he'll spoil the whole affair; he has a Worm in's head as long as a Conger, a brain so barren of all sence, and yet so fruitful of foolish plots, that if he does not all things his own way, yet at least he'll ever be mingling his designs with yours, and go halves with you, so that what with his ignorance, what with his plotting, he'll be sure to ruine you, with an intention to serve you. For my part I had turn'd him off
long since; but that my wise Father, commanded me the contrary.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Still you speak, as if what we did were choice, and not necessity: you know their Uncle is suspicious of me, and consequently jealous of all my Servants; but if we employ yours, who is not suspected, because you are a stranger; I doubt not to get an Assignation with the younger Sister.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Well, use your own way, Camillo: but if it ever succeed, with his managementâ€”

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: You must understand then, Benito, that this old Signior Mario, has two Neeces, with one of which I am desperately in Love, andâ€”

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: aside to him, I understand you already, Sir, and you desire Love reciprocal: Leave your business in my hands, and, if it succeed not, think me no wiser than my Master.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Pray take me with you. These Sisters are great Beauties and vast Fortunes; but, by a Clause in their Fathers Will, if they Marry without their Uncles Consent, are to forfeit all. Their Uncle, who is covetous, and base to the last degree, takes advantage of this Clause, and under pretence of not finding fit Matches for them, denies his consent to all who love 'em.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Denies 'em marriage: very good, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: More than this, he refuses access to any Suitor, and immures 'em in a mean appartment on the garden side, where he barbarously debars 'em from all humane Socitey.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Uses them most barbarously: Still better and better.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: The younger of these Sisters, Violetta, I have seen often in the Garden, from the Balcony in this Chamber, which looks into it, have divers times shot Tickets on the point of an Arrow, which She has taken, and by the signes she made me I find they were not ill receiv'd.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I'll tell you now, just such an Amour as this had I once with a young Lady, thatâ€”

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Quote your self agen, you Rogue, and my feet shall renew their acquaintance with your Buttocks.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p:
Dear Benito, take care to convey this Ticket to Violetta: I saw her just now go by to the next Chappel; be sure to stand ready to give her Holy-water, and slip the Ticket into the hand of her Woman
Beatrix; And take care the elder Sister Laura sees you not, for she knows nothing of our Amour.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: A word to the wise. Have you no Service to Laura? To Aurelian.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: None that I shall trouble you withall: I'll see first what returns you make from this Voyage, before I put in my venture with you. Away; be gone, Mr. Mercury.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I fly, Mr. Iupiter. Exit.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: This Lady Laura I have seen from your Balcone, and was seen by her: methought, too, she lookt with a languishing eye upon me, as who should say, Are you a man, and have no pitty for a poor distressed Virgin? For my part, I never found so much disposition in my self to Love any woman at first sight: handsome she is, of that I am certain.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And has Wit, I dare assure you; but I have not heard she has admitted of any Gallantry.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Her hour is not come yet; she has not met with a man to Love: when that happens (as I am resolv'd to push my fortune) you shall see that, as her love warms, her vertue will melt down, and dissolve in it; for there's no such Baud to a woman, as her own wit is.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I look upon the Assignation, as certain: Will you promise me to go? You and Benito shall walk in the Garden, while I search the Nymph within the shade; one thing I had forgot to tell you, that our General of the Church, the Duke of Mantoua, and the Prince his Son, are just approaching the Gates of Rome: Will you go see the Ceremony of their Entrance?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: With all my heart. They say, he has behav'd himself gallantly against the French, at their return from Naples: besides, I have a particular knowledge of young Prince Frederick, ever since he was last at our Venetian Carnival.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Away, then, quickly; least we miss the Solemnity.

div.stage: Enter Laura, and Violetta striving about a Letter, which Laura holds.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Let it go, I say:

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I say, let you go.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Nay, sweet Sister Laura.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Nay, dear Violetta, 'tis in vain to contend, I am resolv'd I'll see it. Plucks the Paper from Violetta.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: But I am resolv'd you shall not read it. I know not what authority this is which you assume, or what priviledge a year or two can give you, to use this Soveraignty over me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Do you rebell young Gentlewoman? I'll make you know I have a double right over you: one, as I have more years; and the other as I have more wit.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Though I am not all Ayr and Fire, as you are, yet that little wit I have, will serve to conduct my Affairs, without a Governess.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: No, Gentlewoman, but it shall not: are you fit at Fifteen to be trusted with a Maidenhead? 'Tis as much your betters can manage at full twenty.

lg.l: For 'tis of a nature so subtil,
That, if 'tis not Luted with care
The Spirit will work through the Bottel,
And vanish away into Ayr.
To keep it, there's nothing so hard is,
'Twill go betwixt waking and sleeping,
The Simple too weak for a guard is,
And no Wit would be plagu'd with the keeping.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: For ought I see, you are as little to be trusted with your Madness, as I with my Simplicity; and therefore pray restore my Letter.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: reading it. What's here? An humble Petition for a private Meeting? Are you twittering at that sport already, Mistriss Novice?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: How! I a Novice, at ripe Fifteen? I would have you to know, that I have kill'd my Man before I was Fourteen, and now am ready for another execution.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
A very forward Rose-bud: you open apace, Gentlewoman. I find indeed your desires are quick enough; but where will you have cunning to carry on your business with decency and secrecy? Secrecy, I say, which is a main part of chastity in our Sex. Where
wit, to be sensible of the delicacies of Love? the tenderness of a farewell-sigh? for an absence? the joy of a return? the zeal of a pressing-hand? the sweetness of little quarrels, caus'd, and cur'd, by the excess of Love? and, in short, the pleasing disquiets of the Soul, alwayes restless, and wandring up and down in a paradise of thought, of its own making?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: If I understood not thus much before, I find you are an excellent instructer, and that argues you have had a feeling of the cause in your time too, Sister.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: What have I confess'd before I was aware! She'll find out my inclination to that stranger, whom I have only seen, and to whom I have never spokenâ€” Aside. No, good Violetta, I never was in Love; all my experience is from Playes and Romances: But who is this man, to whom you have promis'd an Assignation?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You'll tell my Uncle.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I hate my Uncle more than you do.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You know the man, 'tis Signior Camillo: his Birth and Fortunes are equal to what I can expect; and he tells me his intentions are Honourable.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Have I not seen him lately in his Balcone, which looks into our Garden, with another handsome Gentleman in his Company, who seems a stranger?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: They are the same. Do you think it a reasonable thing, dear Laura, that my Uncle should keep us up so strictly, that we must be beholden to heresay, to know a young Gallant is in the next house to us?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: 'Tis hard, indeed, to be mew'd like Hawks, and never Man'd: to be lock'd in like Nuns here.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: They that look for Nuns flesh in me shall be mistaken.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Well, What answer have you return'd to this Letter?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: That I would meet him at eight this evening, in the close walk in the Garden, attended onely by Beatrix my Woman.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Who comes with him?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Only his friend's Man Benito; the same who brought me the Letter which you took from me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Stay, let me think a little. Do Camillo, or this Benito, know your Maid Beatrix?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: They have never talk'd with her; but only seen her.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: 'Tis concluded then; you shall meet your Servant, but I'll be your Beatrix: I'll go in stead of her, and counterfeit your waiting-woman: in the dark I may easily pass for her: By this means I shall be present to instruct you; for you are yet a Callow Maid: I must teach you to Peck a little, you may come to Prey for your self in time.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: A little teaching will serve my turn: if the old one left me to my self, I could go near to get my Living.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I find you are eager, and Baiting to be gone already, and I'll not hinder you when your hour approaches. In the mean time go in, and sigh, and think fondly, and ignorantly of your approaching pleasures:

lg.l: Love, in young hearts, is like the must of Wine;
'Tis sweetest then; but elder 'tis more fine. Exeunt.

div.head: ACT. II. SCENE I.
div.stage: Prince Frederick, Aurelian, Camillo, and Ascanio the Princes Page.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: MY Fathers ' antient, and may repose himself, if he pleases, after the Ceremony of his Entrance; but we, who are younger, should think it a sin, to spend any part of day-light in a Chamber. What are your wayes of living here?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Why Sir, we pass our time, either in conversation alone, or in Love alone, or in Love and Conversation together.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Come, explain, explain, my Counsel learned in the Laws of Living.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: For conversation alone; that's either in going to Court, with a Face of Business, and there discoursing of the affairs of Europe, of which, Rome, you know, is the publick Mart; or, at best, meeting the Vertuosi, and there, wearying one another with rehearsing our own works, in Prose and Poetry.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Away with that dry method, I will have none on't. To the next.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Love alone, is either plain wenching, where every Curtizan is your Mistriss, and every Man your Rival; or else, what's worse, plain whining after one Woman: that is, walking before her door by day, and haunting her street by night, with Guittars, dark Lanthorns, and Rondaches.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Which, I take it, is, or will be our case, Camillo.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Neither of these will fit my humour: if your third prove not more pleasant, I shall stick to the old Almaine recreation; the Divine bottel, and the bounteous glass, that tun'd up old Horace to his Odes.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You shall need to have no recourse to that; for Love, and Conversation will do your business: that is, Sir, a most delicious Curtizan, I do not mean down-right Punk, but Punk of more than ordinary sence in Conversation: Punk in Ragou, Punk who playes on the Lute, and Sings; and, to sum up all, Punk who Cooks and Dresses up her self, with Poynant Sawce, to become a new Dish every time she is serv'd up to you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: This I believe, Aurelian, is your method of living, you talk of it so savorily.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: There is yet another more insipid sort of Love and Conversation: as for example, look you there, Sir; the Pointing to the Nunnery Courtship of our Nuns. They talk prettily; but, a Pox on'em, they raise our appetites, and then starve us. They are as dangerous as cold Fruits without Wine, and are never to be us'd but where there are abundance of Wenches in readiness, to qualifie 'em.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p:
But yet they are ever at hand, and easie to come by;
and if you'l believe an experienc'd sinner, easiness in Love is more than half the pleasure of it.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: This way of chatting pleases me; for debauchery, I hate it; and, to Love, is not in my nature, except it be my Friends. Pray, What do you call that Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: 'Tis a House of Benedictines, call'd the Torre di Specchi, where only Ladies of the best Quality are Profess'd.

div.stage: Lucretia and Hippolita appear at the Grates.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Look you yonder, Sir, are two of the pretty Magpies, in white and black: if you will lull your self into a Platonick Dream you may: but, consider your sport will be but dull, when you play without Stakes.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: No matter, I'll fool away an hour of Courtship; for I never yet was engag'd in a serious love, nor I believe can be. Farewell, Gentlemen; at this time I shall dispence with your attendance: nay, without Ceremony, because I would be incognito.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Come then, Aurelian, to our own affairs.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: to Lu. For what Crime, fair Creature, were you condemn'd to this perpetual Prison?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: For Chastity and Devotion, and two or three such melancholly vertues: they first brought me hither, and now must keep me company.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I should rather have guess'd it had been Murder, and that you are veil'd, for fear of doing more mischief wirh those Eyes: for, indeed, they are too sharp to be trusted out of the Scabbard.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Cease, I beseech you, to accuse my Eyes, till they have done some execution on your heart.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But I am out of reach, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Trust not to that; they may shoot at a distance, though they cannot strike you near at hand.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But, if they should kill, you are ne'r the better: there's a Grate betwixt us, and you cannot fetch in the dead Quarry.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Provided we destroy the Enemy, we do not value their dead bodies: but you, perhaps, are in your first error, and think we are rather Captives than Warriours; that we come like Prisoners to the Grate, to beg the Charity of Passengers for their love.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: to Ascanio. Inquire as dexterously as you can, what is the Name and Quality of this Charming Creature.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: to Hip. Be sure, if the Page approaches you, to get out of him his Masters Name. The Prince and Lucretia seem to talk.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: to Asca. By that short whisper which I observ'd you took with your Master, I imagine, Mr. Page, you come to ask a certain question of me.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: By this thy question, and by that whisper with thy Lady, (O thou Nymph of Devotion!) I find I am to impart a secret, and not to ask one: therefore, either confess thou art yet a meer Woman under that Veil, and by consequence most horribly inquisitive, or thou shalt lose thy longing, and know nothing of my Master.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: By my Virginity, you shall tell first.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: You'll break your Oath, on purpose to make the forfeit.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Your Master is call'dâ€”

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: You Lady is Yclip'dâ€”

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: For decency, in all matters of Love, the Man should offer first, you know.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: That needs not, when the Damsel is so willing.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: But I have sworn not to discover first, that her Name is Madam Lucretia; fair, as you see, to a Miracle, and of a most charming conversation; of Royal blood, and Neece to his Holiness; and, if she were not espous'd to Heaven, a Mistriss for a Soveraign Prince.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: After these Encomiums, 'twere vain for me to praise my Master: he is only poor Prince Frederick, otherwise call'd the Prince of Mantoua; liberal, and valiant, discreet and handsome, and, in my simple judgment, a fitter Servant for your Lady, than his old Father, who is a Soveraign.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Dare you make all this good you have said of your Master?

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: Yes, and as much more of my self to you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I defy you upon't, as my Lady's Second.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: As my Masters, I accept it. The time?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Six this evening.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: The place?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: At this Grate.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: The Weapons?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Hands, and it may be Lips.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: 'Tis enough: expect to hear from me.

div.stage: They withdraw and whisper to their Principals.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: to Luc. Madam, I am glad I know my enemy; for since it is impossible to see, and not admire you, the name of Lucretia is the best excuse for my defeat.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Persons, like Prince Frederick, ought not to assault Religious Houses; or to pursue Chastity and Virtue to their last retreat.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A Monastery is no retreat for Chastity; 'tis only a hiding place for bad faces, where they are thrust in Crowds together, like heaps of rubbish out of the way, that the world may not be peopled with deform'd persons, and that such who are out of Play themselves, may pray for a blessing on their endeavours, who are getting handsome Children: and carrying on the work for publick benefit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then you would put off Heaven with your leavings, and use it like them who play at Cards alone, take the Courts for your selves, and give the refuse to the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You mistake me, Madam; I would so contrive it, that Heaven and we might be serv'd at once: we have occasion for Wit and Beauty; now Piety and Ugliness will do as well for Heaven; that playes at one Game, and we at another, and therefore heaven may make its hand with the same Cards that we put out.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I could easily convince you if the argument concern'd me; but I am one of those, whom, for want of wit and beauty, you have condemn'd to Religion: and therefore am your humble Servant to Pray for your handsome Wife and Children.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Heaven forbid, Madam, that I should condemn you, or indeed any handsome woman, to be Religious. No, Madam; the occasions of the World are great and urgent for such as you: and, for my part, I am of opinion, that it is as great a Sin for a Beauty to enter into a Nunnery, as for an ugly woman to stay out of it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The Cares of the World are not yet upon you; but as soon as ever you come to be afflicted with Sickness, or visited with a Wife, you'll be content I should pray for you.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Any where, rather than in a Cloyster; for, truly, I suppose, all your Prayers there will be how to get out of it; and, upon that supposition, Madam, I am come to offer you my service for your redemption. Come, faith, be perswaded, the Church shall lose nothing by it: I'll take you out, and put in two or three Crooked Apostles in your place. Bell rings within.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hark, the Bell rings, I must leave you: 'tis a summons to our Devotion.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Will you leave me for your Prayets, Madam? You may have enough of them at any time, but remember you cannot have a Man so easily.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, I'll say my Beads for you, and that's but Charity, for I believe I leave you in a most deplorable condition.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Not deplorable neither, but a little altred: if I could be in Love, as I am sure I cannot, it should be with her, for I like her conversation strangely.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: Then, as young as I am, Sir, I am before-hand with you; for I am in Love already. I would fain make the first proof of my Manhood upon a Nun: I find I have a mighty grudging to Holy Flesh.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I'll ply Lucretia again, as soon as ever her Devotion's over. Methinks these Nuns divide their time most admirably: from Love to Prayers; from Prayers to Love: that is, just so much Sin, just so much Godliness.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.l: Then I can claim that Sister's Love by merit:
Half Man, half Boy; for her half Flesh, half Spirit. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I'll proceed no farther, if Benito goes: I know his folly will produce some mischief.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: But Violetta desir'd me, in her Note, to bring him, on purpose to pass the time with her Woman Beatrix.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
That objection is easily remov'd: I'll supply Benito's place; the darkness will prevent discovery, and, for my discourse, I'll imitate
the half Wit, and patch'd breeding of a Valet de Chambre.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: But how shall we get rid of him?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Let me alone for that.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Come, Are we ready, Gallants? the Clock's upon the stroke of Eight.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But we have alter'd our resolution: we go another way to night.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I hope you have not broke my Assignation.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why do you hope so?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Because my reputation is engag'd in't: I'ave stipulated upon my honour that you shall come.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I shall beat you if you follow me. Go, Sirrah, and adjourn to the great looking-glass, and let me hear no more from you till to morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Sir, my fidelity, and, if I may be so vain, my discretion may stand you in some stead.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Well, come along then, they are brave Fellows who have challeng'd us, you shall have fighting enough, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: How, Sir, Fighting?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You may scape with the loss of a Leg, or an arm, or some such transitory limb.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: No, Sir; I have that absolute obedience to your commands, that I will bridle my courage, and stay at home. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: You took the only way to be rid of him. There's the wall: behind yond pane of it we'll set up the Ladder. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Remember your waiting-womans part, Laura.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I warrant you, I'll wait on you by night as well as I govern'd you by day.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Hark, I hear foot-steps; and now, methinks, I see something approaching us.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: They are certainly the Men whom we expect.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I hear Womens voices.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: We are right, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Violetta, my Love!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My dear Camillo!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: O speak those words again: my own name never sounded so sweetly to me, as when you spoke it, and made me happy by adding Dear to it.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Speak softly then. I have stoln these few minutes from my watchful Uncle and my Sister, and they are as full of danger as they are of love. Something within me checks me too, and sayes, I was too forward in ventring thus to meet you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: You are too fearful rather, and fear's the greatest enemy to Love.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: But night will hide my blushes, when I tell you I love you much, or I had never trusted my virtue and my person in your hands.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: The one is sacred, and the other safe; but this auspicious minute is our first of near converse. May I not hope that favour, which strangers, in civility, my claim even from the most reserv'd?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I fear you'll censure me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Yes, as the blest above tax heaven for making them so happy. They walk farther off.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: stepping towards Lau. Damsel of darkness, advance, and meet my flames.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: stepping forward. Right trusty Valet, heard, but yet unseen, I have advanced one step on reputation.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Now, by laudable custome, I am to love thee vehemently.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: We should do well to see each other first: You know 'tis ill taking Money without light.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
O, but the coyn of Love is known by the weight only, and
you may feel it in the dark: Besides, you know 'tis Prince-like to Love without seeing.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: But then you may be serv'd as Princes are sometimes.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Let us make haste however, and dispatch a little Love out of the way: we may do it now with ease, and save our selves a great deal of trouble, if we take it in time, before it grows too fast upon our hands.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Fie, no; let us Love discreetly, we must manage our passion, and not love all our love out at one meeting, but leave some for another time.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I am for applying the Plaister whilst the wound is green, 'twill heal the better. Takes her by the hand.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Let go my hand: What crime has the poor wretch committed that you press it thus? I remember no mischief it has done you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: O 'tis a hainous malefactour, and is press'd by Law, because it will confess nothing. Come, withdraw a little farther, we have urgent business with one another.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: 'Twere a shame to quit my ground upon the first charge; yer if you please to take truce a little, I will consent to go behind the Lovers, and listen with you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I wonder you defer'd the Proposition so long. I were neither true Valet, nor you true Woman if we could not Eves-drop.

div.stage: They retire behind the other two, who come forward upon the Stage.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: kissing Violetta's hand. Give me another yet, and thenâ€”

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And then will you be satisfy'd?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And then I'll ask a thousand more, and ne'r be satisfy'd. Kisses are but thin nourishment, they are too soon digested, and hungry Love craves more.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You feed a Wolf within you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Then feast my Love with a more solid dyet. He makes us now a Misers Feast, and we forbear to take our fill. The silent night, and all these downy hours were made for Lovers: Gently they tread, and softly measure time, that no rude noise may fright the tender Maid, from giving all her soul to melting joyes.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: You do not love me; if you did, you would not
Thus urge your satisfaction in my shame;
At best, I see you would not love me long,
For they who plunder do not mean to stay.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I haste to take possession of my own.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: E're Heaven and holy vows have made it so?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Then witness Heaven, and all these twinkling Starsâ€”

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Hold, hold; you are distemper'd with your love:
Time, place, and strong desires now swear, not you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Is not Love love without a Priest and Altars?
The Temples are inanimate, and know not
What Vows are made in them; the Priest stands ready
For his hire, and cares not what hearts he couples,
Love alone is marriage.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I never will receive these Mid-night Vows;
But when I come hereafter to your Arms,
I'll bring you a sincere, full, perfect bliss,
Then you will thank me that I kept it so,
And trust my faith hereafter.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: There's your destiny, Lover mine: I am to be honest by infection; my Lady will none you see.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Truth is, they are a lost couple, unless they learn grace by our example. Come, shall we begin first, and shame them both Takes her by the hand again.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: You'll never be warn'd of this hand, Benito.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis so soft, as it were made on purpose to take hearts, and handle them without hurting. These Taper fingers too, and even joynts, so supple, that methinks I mould 'em as they pass through mine: nay, in my conscience, th' it be nonsence to say it, your hand feels white too.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Methinks yours is not very hard, for a Serving-mans: but where, in the name of wonder, have you learn'd to talk so courtly? you are a strange Valet de Chambre.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And you are as strange a Waiting-woman: you have so stab'd me with your Repartees to night, that I should be glad to change the weapon to be reveng'd on you.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: These, I suppose, are fragments which you learn'd from your wild Master Aurelian: many a poor woman has pass'd through his hands, with these very words. You treat me just like a Serving-man, with the cold Meat which comes from your Masters Table.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
You could never have suspected me for using my Masters wit, if you had not been guilty of purloining from your Lady. I am
told, that Laura, your Mistresses Sister, has wit enough to confound a hundred Aurelians.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I shall do your commendations to Laura for your complement.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And I shall not fail to revenge my self by informing Aurelian of yours.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: The poor souls shall not lose by the bargain, though my foolish gadding Masters have disappointed them. That Ladder of ropes was doubtless left there by the young Lady in hope of them.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Hark, I hear a noise in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I fear we are betray'd.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Fear nothing, Madam, but stand close.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Now, Benito, is the time to hold forth thy tallent, and to set up for thy self. Yes, Ladies, you shall be Serenaded, and when I have display'd my gifts, I'll retire in Triumph over the Wall, and hug my self for the adventure. He fums on the Guittar.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Let us make haste, Sister, and get into Covert, this Musick will raise the House upon us immediately.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Alass, we cannot, the damn'd Musician stands just in the door where we should pass.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Singing. Eveillez vous, Belles endormies;
Eveillez vous: car il est jour:
Mettez la tete a la fenestre
Vous entendrez parler d'amour.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: aside to Cam. Camillo, this is my incorrigible rogue; and I dare not call him Benito, for fear of discovering my self not to be Benito.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: The alarm's already given through the house. Ladies, you must be quick: secure your selves, and leave us to shift.
Within. This way, this way.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I hear'em coming; and, as ill luck will have it, just by that quarter where our Ladder is plac'd.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Let us hide in the dark walk till they are past.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But then Benito will be caught, and being known to be my man, will betray us.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I hear some in the Garden: Sure they are the Ladies, that are taken with my melody. To't again Benito; this time I will absolutely inchant 'em. Fums again.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: He's at it again. Why Benito, Are you mad?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ah, Madam! Are you there? this is such a favour to your poor unworthy Servant.

lg.l: But still between kissing Amintas did say,
Fair Phillis look up, and you'll turn night to day.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Come away, you unsufferable rascal, the House is up, and will be upon us immediately.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: O Gemini, Is it you Sir?
Within. This way; follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Leave your scraping and croaking, and step with us into this Arbor.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Scraping and Croaking! 'Sfoot, Sir, either grant I sing and play to a Miracle, or I'll justifie my Musick, though I am caught, and hang'd for't.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Where is this Serenading Rascall? If I find him, I'll make him an example to all midnight Caterwaulers, of which this Fidler is the lewdest.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: O that I durst but Play my Tune out to convince him! Soul of harmony! Is this lewd?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Peace, dear Benito: We must flatter him.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Singing softly. Mettez la tete: the Notes which follow are so sweet, Sir, I must sing 'em, though it be my ruinâ€” Parler d' amour. Laura and Violetta in the Balcone.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Yes, we are safe, Sister; but they are yet in danger.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: They are just upon 'em:

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: We must do something: Help, help; Thieves, thieves; we shall be murder'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Where? Where are they?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Here, Sir, at our Chamber door, and we are run into the Balcone for shelter: Dear Uncle, come and help us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Back again quickly: I durst have sworn they had been in the Garden. 'Tis an Ignis fatuus I think that leads us from one place to another. Exeunt Mar. and Servants.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: They are gone. My dear Camillo, make haste, and preserve your self.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: May our next Meeting prove more propitious.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: to Benito. Come, Sirrah, I shall make you sing another note when you are at home.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Such another word, and I'le sing again.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Set the Ladder, and mount first, you Rogue.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Mount first your self, and fear not my delaying:
If I am caught, they'll spare me for my playing.
Vous entendrez parler d'amour. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: ACT. III. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: IAscanio, and Hippolita at the Grate.
See you have kept touch, Brother,

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: As a man of honour ought, Sister, when he is challeng'd: and now, according to the Laws of Duel, the next thing is to strip, and, in stead of seconds, to search one another.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: We'll strip our hands, if you please, Brother; for they are the only weapons we must use.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: That were to invite me to my loss, Sister; I could have made a full meal in the World, and you would have me take up with hungry commons in the Cloyster. Pray mend my fare, or I am gone.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O, Brother, a hand in a Cloyster, is fare like flesh in Spain, 'tis delicate, because 'tis scarce. You may be satisfy'd with a hand, as well as I am pleas'd with the Courtship of a Boy.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: You may begin with me Sister, as Milo did, by carrying a Calfe first, you may learn to carry an Oxe hereafter: In the mean time produce your hand, I understand Nuns-flesh better than you imagine: give it me, you shall see how I will worry it. She gives her hand. Now Could not we thrust out our lips, and contrive a Kiss too?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Yes, we may; but I have had the experience of it: it will be but half flesh, half Iron.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: Let's try however.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Hold, Lucretia is here.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: Nay, if you come with odds upon me, 'tis time to call Seconds. Ascanio Hems.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir, though your Song was pleasant, yet there was one thing amiss in it, that was your Rallying of Religion.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Do you speak well of my Friend Love, and I'll try to speak well of your friend Devotion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I can never speak well of Love: 'twas to avoid it that I entred here.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Then, Madam, you have met your Man: for, to confess the truth to you, I have but counterfeited Love to try you; for I never yet could love any Woman: and, since I have seen you, and do not, I am certain now I shall scape for ever.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You are the best man in the World, if you continue this resolutionâ–ª Pray, then, let us vow solemnly these two things: the first, to esteem each other better than we do all the world besides; the next, never to change our amity to love.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Agreed Madam: shall I kiss your hand on't?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That's too like a Lover: or, if it were not, the narrowness of the Grate will excuse the ceremony.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: No, but it will not, to my knowledge: I have try'd every bar many a fair time over, and, at last, have found out one where a hand may get through, and be gallanted.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: giving her hand. There, Sir; 'tis a true one.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: kissing it. This, then, is a Seal to our perpetual friendship; and a defyance to all Love.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That seducer of virtue.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: That disturber of quiet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That madness of youth.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: That dotage of old age.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That enemy to good humour.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: And, to conclude all, that reason of all unreasonable actions

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: This Doctrine is abominable, do not believe it Sister.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: No, if I do, Brother, may I never have comfort from sweet youth at my extremity.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But remember one article of our friendship, that though we banish Love, we do not Mirth, nor Gallantry; for I declare, I am for all extravagancies, but just loving.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Just my own humour; for I hate gravity and melancholy next to love.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: Now it comes into my head, the Duke of Mantoua makes an entertainment to night in Masquerade: if you love extravagancy so well, Madam, I'll put you into the head of one; lay by your Nun-ship for an hour or two, and come amongst us in disguise.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: My Boy is in the right, Madam. Will you venture?
I'll furnish you with Masking-habits.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O my dear Sister, never refuse it: I keep the Keyes you know, I'll warrant you well' return before we are miss'd. I do so long to have one fling into the sweet World again before I die. Hang't, at worst, 'tis but one sin more, and then we'll repent for all together.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p:
But if I catch you in the World, Sister, I'll make
you have a better opinion of the Flesh and the Devil for ever after.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If it were known, I were lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: How should it be known? you have her on your side, there, that keeps the Keyes: and, put the worst, that you are taken in the World; the World's a good World to stay in; and there are certain occasions of waking in a morning, that may be more pleasant to you than your Matins.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Fie, Friend, these extravagancies are a breach of Articles in our Friendship: but well, for once, I'll venture to go out; Dancing and Singing are but petty transgressions.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: My Lord, here's company approaching: we shall be discover'd.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Adieu then, jusqu'a revoir; Ascanio shall be with you immediately, to conduct you.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: How, Will you disguise, Sister? Will you be a Man, or a Woman?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: A Woman, Brother Page, for life: I should have the strangest thoughts if I once wore Breeches.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: A Woman, say you? Here's my hand, if I meet you in place convenient, I'll do my best to make you one. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: But, Why thus melancholy, with Hat pull'd down, and the hand on the Region of the Heart, just the reverse of my Friend Aurelian, of happy memory?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Faith, Camillo, I am asham'd on't, but cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: But to be in Love with a Waiting-woman! with an eater of Fragments, a Simperer at lower end of a Table, with mighty Golls, rough-grain'd, and red with Starching, those discouragers and abettors of elevated love!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I could Love Deformity it self, with that good humour. She who is arm'd with Gayety and Wit, needs no other Weapon to conquer me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p:
We Lovers are the great Creators of wit in our Mistrisses. For Beatrix, she a meer utterer of Yes and No, and has no more
Sence than what will just dignifie her to be an arrant waiting-woman: that is, to lye for her Lady, and take your Money.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: It may be then I found her in the exaltation of her wit; for, certainly, women have their good and ill dayes of talking, as they have of looking.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: But, however, she has done you the courtisy to drive out Laura: and so one Poyson has expell'd the other.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Troth, not absolutely neither; for I dote on Laura's beauty, and on Beatrix's wit: I am wounded with a forked Arrow, which will not easily be got out.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Not to lose time in fruitless complaints, let us pursue our new contrivance, that you may see your two Mistresses, and I my one.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: That will not now be difficult: this plot's so laid, that I defy the Devil to make it miss. The Woman of the house, by which they are to pass to Church, is brib'd; the Ladies are, by her, acquainted with the design; and we need only to be there before them, and expect the prey, which will undoubtedly fall into the net.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Your Man is made safe, I hope, from doing us any mischief.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: He has dispos'd of himself, I thank him, for an hour or two: the Fop would make me believe that an unknown Lady is in love with him, and has made him an Assignation.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: If he should succeed now, I should have the worse opinion of the Sex for his sake.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Never doubt but he'll succeed: your brisk Fool that can make a Leg, is ever a fine Gentleman among the Ladies, because he's just of their tallent, and they understand him better than a Wit..

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Peace, the Ladies are coming this way to the Chappel, and their Jaylor with 'em: let 'em go by without saluting, to avoid suspicion; and let us go off to prepare our Engine.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I must have a look before we go. Ah, you little Divine rogue! I'le be with you immediately.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Look you, Sister, there are our Friends, but take no notice.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I saw them. Was not that Aurelian with Camillo?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I like him strangely. If his person were joyn'd with Benito's Wit, I know not what would become of my poor heart.

div.stage: Enter Fabio, and whispers with Mario.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Stay, Neeces, I'll but speak a word with Fabio, and go with you immediately.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I see, Sister, you are infinitely taken with Benito's wit; but I have heard he is a very conceited Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: They who told you so, were horribly mistaken: you shall be judge your self, Violetta; for, to confess frankly to you, I have made him a kind of an appointment.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: How! Have you made an Assignation to Benito? A Serving-man! a Trencher-carrying Rascal!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Good words, Violetta! I only sent to him from an unknown Lady near this Chappel, that I might view him in passing by, and see if his person were answerable to his conversation.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: But how will you get rid of my Uncle?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: You see my project; his man Fabio is brib'd by me, to hold him in discourse.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: In my conscience this is he. Lord, what a Monster of a Man is there! With such a Workiday-rough-hewn face too! for, faith, Heaven has not bestow'd the finishing upon't.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible this should be Benito; yet he stalks this way: from such a piece of animated Timber, sweet Heaven deliver me.

sp.speaker: Benito
sp.p: aside. This must of necessity be the Lady who is in Love with me. See, how she surveyes my Person! Certainly one Wit knows another by instinct. By that old Gentleman, it should be the Lady Laura too. Hum! Benito, thou art made for ever.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: He has the most unpromising Face, for a Wit, I ever saw; and yet he had need have a very good one, to make amends for his face. I am half cur'd of him already.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: What means all this Surveying, Madam? you bristle up to me, and wheel about me, like a Turkey-cock that is making Love: Faith, How do you like my Person, ha?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I dare not praise it, for fear of the old Complement, that you should tell me, 'Tis at my service. But, pray, Is your Name Benito?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Signior Benito, at your service, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: And have you no Brother, or any other of your Name, one that is a Wit, attending on Signior Aurelian?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: No, I can assure your Ladiship: I my self am the only wit who does him the honour, not to attend him, but to bear him company.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: But sure it was another you, that waited on Camillo in the Garden, last night.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: It was no other Me, but me Signior Benito.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: 'Tis most certain.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Then I would advise you to go thither again, and look for the wit which you have left there, for you have brought very little along with you: your voice, methinks, too, is much alter'd.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Only a little over-strain'd, or so, with Singing.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: How slept you, after your adventure?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Faith, Lady, I could not sleep one wink, for Dreaming of you.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Not sleep for Dreaming! When the place falls, you shall be Bull-master-General at Court.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Et tu Brute! Do you mistake me for a Fool too? then, I find there's one more of that opinion besides my Master.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Sister, look to your self, my Uncle's returning.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I am glad on't; he has done my business: he has absolutely cur'd me. Lord, that I could be so mistaken!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I told you what he was.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: He was quite another thing last night: never was Man so alter'd in four and twenty hours. A pure Clown, meer Elementary earth, without the least spark of Soul in him!

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: But, tell me truly, Are not you in Love with me? Confess the truth: I love plain-dealing: you shall not find me refractory.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Away, thou Animal; I have found thee out for a high and mighty fool, and so I leave thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come, now I am ready for you; as little Devotion, and as much good Huswifery as you please: take example by me; I assure you no body debauches me to Church, except it be in your Company. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I am undone for ever: What shall I do with my self? I'll run into some Desart, and there I'll hide my opprobrious head. No, hang't, I won't neither; all Wits have their failings sometimes, and have the fortune to be thought fools once in their lives. Sure this is but a copy of her countenance; for my heart's true to me, and whispers to me, she loves me still: well, I'll trust in my own merits, and be confident.

div.stage: A noise of throwing down water within.
Enter Mario, Fabio, Laura, and Violetta.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: shaking her Cloaths, Oh Sir, I am wet quite through my Cloaths, I am not able to endure it.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Was there ever such an insolence?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Send in to see who lives there: I'll make an example of'em.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Here's the Woman of the House her self, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fron.
sp.p: Sir, I submit, most willingly, to any punishment you shall inflict upon me; for, though I intended nothing of an affront to these sweet Ladies, yet I can never forgive my self the misfortune of which I was the innocent occasion.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: O I am ready to faint away.

sp.speaker: Fron.
sp.p: Alass, poor sweet Lady, she's young and tender, Sir: I beseech you, give me leave to repair my offence, with offering my self, and poor House, for her accommodation.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I know that Woman: there's some villanous Plot in this, I'll lay my life on't. Now, Benito, cast about for thy credit, and recover all again.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Go into the Coach, Neeces, and bid the Coach-man drive apace. As for you, Mistriss, your smooth Tongue shall not excuse you.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: By your favour, Sir, I'll accept of the Gentlewoman's civility; I cannot stir a step farther.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Come in, sweet Buds of Beauty, you shall have a Fire in an inner Chamber, and if you please to repose your self a while, Sir, in another Room, they shall come out, and wait on you immediately.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, if it must be so.

sp.speaker: Fron.
sp.p: whispering the Ladies. Your Friends are ready in the Garden, and will be with you as soon as we have shaken off your Uncle.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: A Cheat, a cheat, a rank one; I smell it, old Sir, I smell it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What's the matter with the Fellow? Is he distracted?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: No, 'tis you are more likely to be distracted; but that there goes some wit to the being mad, and you have not the least grain of wit to be gull'd thus grosly.

sp.speaker: Fron.
sp.p: What does the fellow mean?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: The Fellow means to detect your villany, and to recover his lost reputation of a Wit..

sp.speaker: Fron.
sp.p: Why, Friend, What villany? I hope my house is a civil house.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Yes, a very civil one; for my master lay in of his last Clap there, and was treated very civilly to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How's this, How's this?

sp.speaker: Fron.
sp.p: Come, you are a dirty Fellow, and I am known to be a person thatâ€”

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Yes, you are known to be a person thatâ€”

sp.speaker: Fron.
sp.p: Speak your worst of me, What person am I known to be?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Why, if you will have it, you are a little better than a procuress: you carry messages betwixt party and party, and, in one word Sir, she's as arrant a Fruit-woman as any is about Rome.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, if she be a Fruit-woman, my Neeces shall not enter into her doors.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: You had best let them enter, you do not know how they may fructify in her house, for I heard her with these Eares whisper to'm, that their Friends were within call.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This is palpable, this is manifest; I shall remember you, Lady Fruiterer, I shall have your baskets search'd when you bring Oranges again. Come away, Neeces; and thanks honest Fellow for thy discovery. Exeunt Mario and Women.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Hah couragio: Il Diavolo e morto. Now I think I have tickled it; this discovery has re-instated me into the Empire of my wit again. Now, in the pomp of this atchievement, will I present my self before Madam Laura, with a Behold, Madam, the happy restauration of Benito.
sp.stage: Enter Aurelian, Camillo, and Frontona, overhearing him.
sp.p: Oh, now, that I had the Mirrour, to behold my self in the fulness of my glory! and, oh, that the domineering Fop my Master were in presence, that I might triumph over him! that I might even contemn the wretched wight, the mortal of a groveling Soul, and of a debased understanding.

stage.hi: He looks about him and sees his Master.

sp.p: How the Devil came these three together? nothing vexes me but that I must stand bare to him, after such an enterprize as this is.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Nay, put on, put on again, sweet Sir; Why should you be uncover'd before the Fop your Master? the wretched wight, the mortal of a groveling Soul.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, you may make bold with your self at your own pleasure: But for all that, a little bidding would make me take your Counsel and be cover'd, as Affairs go now.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: If it be lawful for a man of a debased understanding to confer with such an exalted wit, pray what was that glorious atchievement which rapt you into such an extasy?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: 'Tis a sign you know well how matters go, by your asking me so impertinent a question.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: putting off his Hat to him. Sir, I beg of you, as your most humble Master, to be satisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir; at present I am not at leisure for conference. But hark you, Sir, by the way of friendly advice, one word, henceforward tell me no more of the adventure of the Garden, nor of the great Looking-glassâ€”

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You mean the Mirror.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Yes, the Mirror; tell me no more of that, except you could behold in it a better, a more discreet, or a more able face for stratagem, than I can, when I look there.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But, to the business; What is this famous enterprise?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Be satisfy'd, without troubling me farther, the business is done, the Rogues are defeated, and your Mistriss is secur'd: if you would know more, demand it of that Criminal, Pointing to Frontona. and ask her how she dares appear before you, after such a signal treachery, or before me, after such an overthrow?

sp.speaker: Fron.
sp.p: I know nothing, but only that, by your Masters Order, I was to receive the two Ladies into my house, and you prevented it.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: By my Master's Order? I'll ne'r believe it. This is your stratagem, to free your self, and defraud me of my reward.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I'll witness what she sayes is true.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I am deaf to all asseverations that make against my honour.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I'll swear it then. We two were the two Rogues, and you the discoverer of our Villany.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Then, woe, woe, to poor Benito! I find my abundance of wit has ruin'd me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But come a little nearer: I would not receive a good office from a Servant, but I would reward him for his diligence.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Virtue, Sir, is its own reward: I expect none from you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Since it is so, Sir, you shall lose no further time in my service: henceforward pray know me for your humble Servant; for your Master I am resolv'd to be no longer.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Nay, rather than so, Sir, I beseech you let a good honest sufficient beating attone the difference.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: 'Tis in vain.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I am loath to leave you without a guide.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: He's at it again, do you hear, Camillo?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Prethy, Aurelian, be molify'd, and beat him.

sp.speaker: Fron.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, hear reason, and lay't on, for my sake.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I am obdurate.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: But, What will your Father say, if you part with him?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I care not.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Well, Sir, since you are so peremptory, remember I have offer'd you satisfaction, and so long my conscience is at ease: what a Devil, before I'lll offer my self twice to be beaten, by any Master in Christendome, I'll starve, and that's my resolution, and so your Servant that was Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I am glad I am rid of him; he was my Evil Genius, and was alwayes appearing to me, to blast my undertakings: Let me send him never so farr off, the Devil would be sure to put him in my way, when I had any thing to execute. Come, Camillo, now we have chang'd the Dice, it may be we shall have better fortune.

div.head: SCENE. II.
div.stage: Enter the Duke of Mantoua in Masquerade, Frederick, Valerio, and others. On the other side Enter Lucretia, Hippolita, and Ascanio.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: to Asca. The Prince I know already, by your description of his Masking-habit; but, Which is the Duke his Father?

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: He whom you see talking with the Prince, and looking this way. I believe he has observ'd us.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If he has not, I am resolv'd we'll make our selves as remarkable as we can: I'll exercise my tallent of Dancing.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And I mine of Singing.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: to Frederick. Do you know the Company which came in last?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I cannot possibly imagine who they are: at least I will not tell youâ€” Aside.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: There's something very uncommon in the Ayre of one of them.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Please you, Sir, I'll discourse with her, and see if I can satisfie your Highness.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Stay, there's a Dance beginning, and she seems as if she wou'd make one.

lg.l: Long betwixt Love and fear Phillis tormented,
Shun'd her own wish yet at last she consented:
But loath that day shou'd her blushes discover,
Come gentle Night She said,
Come quickly to my aid,
And a poor Shamefac'd Maid
Hide from her Lover.
Now cold as Ice I am, now hot as Fire,
I dare not tell my self my own desire;
But let Day fly away, and let Night hast her:
Grant yee kind Powers above,
Slow houres to parting Love,
But when to Bliss we move,
Bid 'em fly faster.
How sweet it is to Love when I discover,
That Fire which burns my Heart, warming my Lover;
'Tis pitty Love so true should be mistaken:
But if this Night he be
False or unkinde to me,
Let me dye ere I see
That I'me forsaken.

sp.p: After the Dance. My curiosity redoubles, I must needs hale that unknown Vessel, and enquire whither she's bound, and what fraight she carries.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: She's not worth your trouble, Sir: she'll either prove some common Courtizan in disguise, or at best, some homely person of Honour, that only dances well enough to invite a sight of her self, and would look ill enough to fright you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: That's maliciously said; all I see of her is charming, and I have reason to think her face is of the same piece, at least I'll try my fortune.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What an unlucky accident is this! If my father should discover her, she's ruin'd: if he does not, yet I have lost her conversation to night.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: 'Tis the Duke himself who comes to court you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Peace, I'll fit him; for I have been inform'd to the least title of his actions since he came to Town.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: to Lucretia. Madam, the Duke of Mantoua, whom you must needs imagine to be in this company, has sent me to you, to know what kind of face there is belonging to that excellent shape, and to those charming motions which he observ'd so lately in your Dancing.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Tell his Highness, if you please, that there is a Face within the Masque, so very deform'd, that if it were discover'd, it would prove the worst Vizor of the two; and that, of all Men, he ought not to desire it should be expos'd, because then something would be found amiss in an entertainment which he has made so splendid and magnificent.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: The Duke I am sure would be very proud of your complement, but it would leave him more unsatisfy'd than before, for he will find in it so much of Gallantry, as, being added to your other graces, will move him to a strange temptation of knowing you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I should still have the more reason to refuse him; for 'twere a madness, when I had charm'd him by my motion and converse, to hazard the loss of that conquest by my eyes.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: aside. I am on fire till I discover her.
At least, Madam, tell me of what Family you are.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Will you be satisfy'd if I tell you I am of the Colonne; you have seen Iulia of that House.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Then you are she.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Have I not her Stature most exactly?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: As near as I remember.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But, by your favour, I have nothing of her shape; for, if I may be so vain to praise my self, she's a little thicker in the shoulders, and, besides, she moves ungracefully.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Then you are not she again.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No not she: but you have forgotten Emilia of the Ursini, whom the Duke saluted yesterday at her Balcone, when he enter'd. Her Ayre and Motionâ€”

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Are the very same with yours. Now I am sure I know you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But there's too little of her to make a Beauty: my stature is much more advantagious.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You have cozen'd me again.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, I find at last I must confess my self. What think you of Eugenia Beata? the Duke seem'd to be infinitely pleas'd last night, when my Brother presented me to him at the Belvedere.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Now I am certain you are she; for you have both her stature, and her motion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But, if you remember your self a little better, there's some small difference in our wit: for she has indeed the Ayre and Beauty of a Roman Lady, but all the dulness of a Dutch-woman.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I see, Madam, you are resolv'd to conceal your self, and I am as fully resolv'd to know you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: See which of our resolutions will take place.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I come from the Duke, and can assure you he is of an humour to be obey'd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And I am of an humour not to obey him. But, Why should he be so curious?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: If you would have my opinion, I believe he is in love with you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Without seeing me?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Without seeing all of you: Love is love, let it wound us from what part it please; and if he have enough from your shape and conversation, his business is done, the more compendiously, without the face.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But the Duke cannot be taken with my conversation, for he never heard me speak.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: aside. ' Slife, I shall discover my self. Yes, Madam, he stood by, incognito, and heard me speak with you: butâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I wish he had trusted to his own courtship, and spoke himself; for it gives us a bad impression of a Princes wit, when we see fools in favour about his person.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What ever I am, I have it in Commission from him to tell you, He's in Love with you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The good old Gentleman may dote, if he so pleases; but love, and fifty years old, are stark non-sense.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: But some men, you know, are green at fifty.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, in their understandings.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You speak with great contempt of a Prince, who has some reputation in the world.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No; 'tis you that speak with contempt of him, by saying he is in love at such an Age.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Then, Madam, 'tis necessary you should know him better for his reputation: and, that shall be, though he violate the Laws of Masquerade, and force you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I suspected this, from his violent temper. Aside. Sir, the Emperour's Ambassador is here, in Masquerade, and I believe this to be his Lady: it were well if you inquir'd of him, before you forc'd her to discover.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Which is the Ambassador?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That farthermost. Duke retires farther.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: to Luc. Take your opportunity to escape, while his back is turn'd, or you are ruin'd. Ascanio, wait on her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I am so frighted, I cannot stay to thank you.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: to Fred. 'Tis a mistake, the Ambassador knows nothing of her: I'm resolv'd I'll know it of her self, ere she shall depart. Ha! Where is she? I left her here.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: aside. Out of your reach, Father mine, I hope.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: She has either shifted places, or else slipt out of the Assembly.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I have look'd round: she must be gone, Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
