sp.p: She must not be gone, Sir. Search for her every where: I will have her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Has she offended your Highness?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Peace, with your impertinent questions. Come hither, Valerio.

sp.speaker: Valerio.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: O, Valerio, I am desperately in love: that Lady, with whom you saw me talking, hasâ€” But I lose time; she's gone; haste after her; find her; bring her back to me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: If it be possible.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: It must be possible; the quiet of my life depends upon it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Which way took she?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Go any way, every way; ask no questions: I know no more, but that she must must be had. Exit Valerio.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Sir, the assembly will observe, thatâ€”

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Damn the assembly, 'tis a dull insignificant crowd, now she is not here: break it up, I'll stay no longer.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: aside. I hope she's safe, and then this fantastick love of my Fathers will make us sport too morrow. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Now, that we are safe at the gate of our Covent, methinks the adventure was not unpleasant.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And now that I am out of danger, Brother, I may tell you what a Novice you are in love, to tempt a young Sister into the wide World, and not to show her the difference betwixt that and her Cloyster: I find I may venture safely with you another time.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: O, Sister, you play the Brazen-head with me; you give me warning when Time's past; but that was no fit opportunity: I hate to snatch a morsel of Love, and so away; I am for a set-meal, where I may enjoy my full gust; but when I once fall on, you shall find me a brave man upon occasion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis time we were in our Cells. Quick, Hippolita, where's the Key?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Here, in my pocketâ€” No, 'tis in my other Pocketâ€” Haâ€” 'tis not there, neither. I am sure I put it in one of them.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What should we do, if it should be lost now?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I have search'd my self all over, and cannot find it.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: A woman can never search her self all over; let me search you, Sister.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Is this a time for Raillery? Oh, sweet heaven! speak comfort quickly; Have you found it?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Speak you comfort, Madam, and tell me you have it, for I am too sure that I have none on't.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O unfortunate that we are! day's breaking; the handy-crafts shops begin to open. Clock strikes.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: The Clock strikes two: within this half hour we shall be call'd up to our Devotions. Now, good Ascanioâ€” Alass he's gone too! we are left miserable, and forlorn.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: We have not so much as one place in the Town for a Retreat.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O, for a Miracle in our time of need! that some kind good-natur'd Saint would take us up, and heave us over the Wall into our Cells.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Dear Sister, Pray; for I cannot: I have been so sinful, in leaving my Cloyster for the World, that I am asham'd to trouble my Friends above to help me.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Alass, Sister, with what face can I Pray, then! Yours were but little vanities; but I have sin'd swingingly, against my Vow; yes, indeed, Sister, I have been very wicked; for I wish'd the Ball might be kept perpetually in our Cloyster, and that half the handsome Nuns in it might be turn'd to Men, for the sake of the other.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, if I were free from this disgrace, I would never more set foot beyond the Cloyster, for the sake of any Man.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And here I Vow, if I get safe within my Cell, I will not think of Man again these seven years.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: Hold, Hippolita, and make no more rash Vows: if you do, as I live, you shall not have the Key.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: The Key! why, Have it you, Brother?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He does but mock us: I know you have it not, Ascanio.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: Ecce signum; Here it is for you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O, sweet Brother, let me kiss you.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: Hands off, sweet Sister; you must not be forsworn: you vow'd you would not think of a man these seven years.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Ay, Brother, but I was not so hasty, but I had wit enough to cozen the Saint to whom I vow'd; for you are but a Boy, Brother, and will not be a Man these seven years.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But, Where did you find the Key, Ascanio?

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: To confess the truth, Madam, I stole it out of Hippolita's Pocket, to take the Print of it in Wax; for, I'll suppose, you'll give my Master leave to wait on you in the Nunnery-garden, after your Abbess has walk'd the Rounds.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, well, good morrow: when you have slept, come to the Grate for a Letter to your Lord. Now will I have the head-ach, or the Meagrim, or some excuse, for I am resolv'd I'll not rise to Prayers.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Pray, Brother, take care of our Masking-habits, that they may be forth-coming another time.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: Sleep, sleep, and dream of me, Sister: I'll make it good, if you dream not too unreasonably.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Thus dangers in our Love make joyes more dear;
And Pleasure's sweetest, when 'tis mixt with fear. Exeunt.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCENE I.
div.stage: A Dressing-Chamber. The Masking-habits of Lucretia and Hippolita laid in a Chair.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I Never thought I should have lov'd her. Is't come to this, after all my boastings and declarations against it? Sure I lov'd her before, and did not know it, till I fear'd to lose her: there's the reason. I had never desir'd her, if my Father had not. This is just the longing of a Woman: she never finds the appetite in her self, till she sees the Meat on anothers Plate. I'm glad however, you took the impression of the Key; but 'twas not well to fright them.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: Sir, I could not help it; but here's the effect on't: the Workman sate up all night to make it. Gives a Key

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: This Key will admit me into the Seraglio of the Godly. The Monastery has begun the War, in Sallying out upon the World, and therefore 'tis but just that the World should make Reprizals on the Monastery.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: Alass, Sir, you and Lucretia do but skirmish; 'tis I and Hippolita that make the War: 'tis true, opportunity has been wanting for a Battel, but the forces have been stoutly drawn up on both sides. As for your concernment, I come just now from the Monastery, and have Orders from you Platonick Mistriss to tell you, she expects you this evening in the Garden of the Nunnery; withall, she deliver'd me this Letter for you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Give it me,

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: O, Sir, the Duke your Father!

div.stage: The prince takes the Letter, and thinking to put it up bastily, drops it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Now, Frederick! not abroad yet?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Your last nights entertainment left me so weary, Sir, that I over-slept my self this morning.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I rather envy you, than blame you: our sleep is certainly the most pleasant portion of our lives. For my own part, I spent the night waking, and restless.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Has any thing of moment happen'd to discompose your Highness?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I'll confess my follies to you: I am in love with a Lady I saw last night in Masquerade.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: 'Tis strange she should conceal her self.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: She has, from my best search; yet I took exact notice of her Masking habit, and describ'd it to those whom I employ'd to find her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: aside. 'Sdeath, it lies there unremov'd; and, if he turns himself, full in his eye. Now, now 'twill be discover'd.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: For 'twas extreamly remarkable. I remember very well 'twas a loose long Robe, streak'd black and white, girt with a large Silver Ribband, and the Vizor was a Moor's Face.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.stage: Running to the Chair where the Habits are, sits down.
sp.p: Sir, I beg pardon of your Highness for this Rudeness, I amâ€” O, Ohâ€”

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I am taken so extreamly ill o'the sudden, that I am forc'd to sit before you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Alass, What's your distemper?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A most violent griping, which pulls me together on a heap.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Some cold, I fear, you took last night. Runs to the Door. Who waites there? Call Physitians to the Prince.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ascanio, remove these quickly.

div.stage: Ascanio takes away the habits, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: returning. How do you find your self?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: arising. Much better. Sir: that which pain'd me is remov'd: as it came unexpectedly, so it went as suddenly.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: The Ayre, perhaps, will do you good. If you have health, you may see those Troops drawn out, which I design for Millan.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Shall I wait your Highness?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: No, leave me here with Valerio; I have a little business, which dispatch'd, I'll follow you immediately. Well, What success, Valerio? Exit Frederick.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Our indeavours are in vain, Sir: there has been inquiry made about all the Pallaces in Rome, and neither of the Masking-habits can be discover'd.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Yet, it must be a Woman of Quality. What Paper's that at my foot?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: taking up the Letter. 'Tis Seal'd, Sir, and directed to the Prince.

sp.speaker: Duke,
sp.p: taking the Letter. 'Tis a Womans hand. Has he got a Mistriss in Town so soon? I am resolv'd to open it, though I do not approve my own curiosity. Opens and Reads it.

body.p: Now my fear is over, I can laugh at my last nights adventure: I find that at Fifty all Men grow incorrigible, and Lovers especially; for, certainly, never any Creature could be worse treated than your Father, (How's this, Valerio? I am amaz'd) and yet the good, old, out of fashion Gentleman heard himself Raillied, and bore it with all the patience of a Christian Prince. (Now 'tis plain, the Lady in Masquerade is a Mistriss of my Son's, and the undutiful wretch was in the Plot to abuse me.) Ascanio will tell you the latter part of our misfortune, how hardly we got into the Cloyster, (A Nun too! Oh, the Devil!) when we meet next, pray provide to laugh heartily, for there is subject sufficient for a plentiful fit, and fop enough to spare for another time

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Lucretia! now the Mistery is unfolded.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Do you know her?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: When I was last at Rome, I saw her often; she is near Kinswoman to the present Pope; and, before he placed her in this Nunnery of Benedictines, was the most celebrated Beauty of the Town.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I know I ought to hate this Woman, because she has affronted me thus grossly; but yet I cannot help it, I must love her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But, Sir, you come on too much disadvantage to be your Son's Rival.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I am deaf to all considerations: pr'ythee do not think of giving a Mad-man Counsel: pity me, and cure me, if thou canst; but remember there's but one infallible Medicine, that's enjoyment.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I had forgot to tell you, Sir, that the Governour Don Mario is without, to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Desire him to come in.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am come, Sir, to beg a favour from your Highness, and 'tis on the behalf of my Sister Sophronia, Abbess of the Torr' di Specchi.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, she's Abbess of that very Monastery where your Mistriss is inclos'd. Aside, to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I should be glad to serve any Relation of yours, Don Mario.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Her request is, That you would be pleas'd to grace her Chappel this afternoon. There will be Musick, and some little Ceremony, in the Reception of my two Neeces, who are to be plac'd in Pension there.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Your Neeces, I hear, are fair, and great Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Great vexations I'm sure they are; being daily haunted by a company of wild Fellows, who buz about my house like Flies.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Your design seems reasonable; Women in hot Countryes are like Oranges in cold: to preserve them, they must be perpetually hous'd. I'll bear you company to the Monastery. Come, Valerio; this opportunity is happy beyond our expectation. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: He has smarted sufficiently for this offence: pr'ythee, dear Aurelian, forgive him; he waits without, and appears penitent; I'll be responsible for his future carriage.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: For your sake, then, I receive him into grace.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: at the door. Benito, you may appear, your peace is made.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But, it must be upon conditions.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Any conditions that are reasonable; for, as I am a Wit, Sir, I have not eatenâ€”

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You are in the path of perdition already; that's the principal of our Conditions, you are to be a Wit no more.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, if it be possible, let me be a little Wit still.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No, Sir: you can make a Leg, and Dance; those are no Tallents of a Wit: you are cut out for a brisk foolâ–ª and can be no other.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let me think ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰ Wit, or my heart will break.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: That you will naturally do, as you are a Fool.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Then, no farther medling with adventures, or contrivances of your own: they are all belonging to the Territories of wit, from whence you are banish'd.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: But what if my imagination should really furnish me with someâ€”

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Not a Plot, I hope?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: No, Sir, no Plot; but some expedient then, to molify the word, when your invention has fail'd you?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Think it a temptation of the Devil, and believe it not.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Then farewel all the happiness of my life.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: You know your doom, Benito, and now you may take your choice, whether you will renounce wit, or eating.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I must continue my Body at what rate soever: and the rather, because now there's no farther need of me in your adventures; for I was assur'd, by Beatrix, this morning, that her two Mistrisses are to be put in Pension in the Nunnery of Benedictines, this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Then I am miserable.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And you have defer'd the telling it till it is past time to study for prevention.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Let us run thither immediately, and either perish in't, or free them. You'll assist me with your Sword?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Yes, if I cannot do't to more purpose, with my counsel. Let us first play the fairest of our Game, 'tis time enough to snatch when we have lost it. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: The Duke, Valerio, Attendants. At the other door, Laura, Violetta, Beatrix, Mario. Instrumental and vocal Musick. In the time of which, Enter Aurelian and Camillo. After the Musick, Enter Sophronia, Lucretia, Hippolita, and other Nuns.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: to Valeria, who had whisper'd to him. I needed not those markes to know her. She's one continu'd excellence; she's all over Miracle,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: to the Duke. We know, Sir, we are not capable, by our Entertainments, of adding any thing to your pleasures, and therefore we must attribute this favour of your presence, to your piety and devotion.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You have treated me with Harmony so excellent, that I believ'd my self among a quire of angels; especially, when I beheld so fair a Troop behind you.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Their Beauty, Sir, is wholly dedicated to Heaven, and is no way ambitious of a commendation, which from your mouth might raise a pride in any other of the Sex.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I am impatient, and can bear no longer. Let what will happenâ€”

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Do you not see your ruine inevitable? Draw in a holy place! and in the presence of the Duke!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I do not like Camillo's being here: I must cut short the Ceremony. Whispers Sophronia,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: to Lau. and Violet. Come, fair Cousins, we hope to make the Cloysteral life so pleasing, that it may be an inducement to you to quit the wicked world for ever.

div.p: Take that, and read it at your leasure.
div.stage: Conveyes a Note into his hand.

sp.speaker: Cam
sp.p: A Ticket, as I live, Aurelian.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Steal off, and be thankful: If that be my Beatrix with
Laura, she's most confoundedly ugly. If ever we had come to Love-work, and a Candle had been brought us, I had faln back from that face, like a Buck Rabbet in coupling.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Daughters, the time of our Devotion calls us. All happiness to your Highness.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: to Hip. Little thinks my venerable old Love there, that his Mistriss in Masquerade is so near him. Now do I e'en long to abuse that Fop-gravity again.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Methinks he looks on us.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Farewell, poor love, I am she, I am, for all my demure looks, that treated thee so inhumanely last night.

div.stage: She is going off, after Sophonia.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: following her. Stay Lady; I would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ah! (screaking.)

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: How now, Daughter? What's the meaning of that undecent noise you make?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: aside. If I speak to him, he will discover my voice, and then I am ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: If your name be Lucretia, I have some business of concernment with you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: to Soph. Dear Madam, for Heavens sake make haste into the Cloyster, the Duke pursues me on some ill design.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: to the Duke. 'Tis not permitted, Sir, for Maids once entred into Religion, to hold discourses here of worldly things.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But my discourses are not worldly Madam;
I had a Vision in the dead of night,
Which show'd me this fair Virgin in my sleep,
And told me, that from her I should be taught
Where to bestow large Almes, and great Endowments,
On some near Monastery.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: â€” Stay, Lucretia,
The Holy Vision's will must be obey'd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: aside. He does not know me, sure; and yet I fear Religion is the least of his business with me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I see, Madam, Beauty will be beauty in any habit.
Though I confess, the splendor of a Court
Were a much fitter Scene for yours, then is
A Cloyster'd privacy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: counter-feiting her voice. The World has no temptations for a mind
So fix'd, and rais'd above it,
This humble Cell contains and bounds my wishes.
My Charity gives you my Prayers, and that's all my
Converse with humane kind.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Since when, Madam, have the World and you been upon these equal termes of hostility? time was you have been better friends.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No doubt I have been vain, and sinful; but, the remembrance of those dayes cannot be pleasant to me now, and therefore, if you please, do not refresh their Memory.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Their memory! you speak as if they were Ages past.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You think me still what I was once, a vain, fond, giddy creature; I see, Sir, whether your discourses tend, and therefore take my leave.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I know you see whither my discourses tend, and therefore 'twill not be convenient that you should take your leave. Disguise your self no farther; you are known, as well as you knew me in Masquerade.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I am not us'd enough to the World, to interpret Riddles; therefore, once more, heaven keep you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: This will not do: your voice, your meen, your stature, betray you for the same I saw last night: you know the time and place.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You were not in this Chappel; and, I am bound by vow to stir no farther.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: But you had too much wit to keep that vow.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: If you persist, Sir, in this raving madness,
I can bring witness of my innocence. Is going.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: To save that labour, see if you know that hand, and let that justifie you. (Shows her Letter.)

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What do I see! my ruine is inevitable.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You know you merit it:
You us'd me ill, and now are in my power.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But you, I hope, are much too noble
To destroy the Fame of a poor silly Woman?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Then, in few words, for I am bred a Souldier,
And must speak plain, it is your Love I ask:
If you deny, this Letter is produc'd;
You know the consequence.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I hope I do not:
For, though there are appearances against me,
Enough to give you hope I durst not shun you;
Yet, could you see my heart, 'tis a white Virgin-Tablet,
On which no Characters of earthly love
Were ever writ: and, 'twixt the Prince and me;
If there were any Criminal affection,
May heaven this minuteâ€”

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Swear not; I believe you:
For could I think my Son had e're enjoy'd you,
I should not be his Rival. Since he has not,
I may have so much kindness for my self
To wish that happiness.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You ask me what I must not grant,
Nor if I lov'd you would: you know my vow of Chastity.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Yet again that senceless argument?
The Vows of Chastity can ne're be broken,
Where Vows of secrecy are kept: those I'll swear with you.
But 'tis enough, at present, you know my resolution.
I would perswade, not force you to my Love;
And to that end I give you this nights respite.
Consider all, that you may fear or hope;
And think that on your grant, or your denial,
Depends a double welfare, yours and mine. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A double ruine rather, if I grant: For what can I expect from such a Father, when such a Son betrayes me! Could I think of all Mankind, that Frederick could be base. And, with the vanity of vulgar Souls betray a Virgins fame: one who esteem'd him, and I much fear did more than barely soâ€” But I dare not examine my self farther; for fear of confessing to my own thoughts, a tenderness of which he is unworthy.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I watch'd till your old Gallant was gone, to bring you news of your young one. A mischief on these old dry Lovers, they are good for nothing but tedious talking; Well, yonder's the Prince at the Grate; I hope I need say no more to you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I'll come when I have recover'd my self a little.
I am a wretched creature, Hippolita; the Letter
I writ the Princeâ€”

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I know it, is faln into his Fathers hands by accident. He's as wretched as you too. Well, well, it shall be my part to bring you together; and then, if two young people that have opportunity, can be wretched and melancholyâ€” I'll go before and meet Ascanio. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I am half unwilling to go, because I must be accessary to her Assignation with Ascanio; but, for once, I'll meet the Prince in the Garden walk: I am glad however that he is less criminal than I thought him. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Hippolita, Ascanio, meeting Laura and Violetta.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I hear some walking this way. Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: We are the two new Pensioners, Laura and Violetta.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Go in, to your devotion: these undue hours of walking savour too much of worldly thoughts.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Let us retire to the Arbor, where, by this time, I believe our Friends are. Goodnight, Sister.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Good Angels guard you. Exit Laura and Violetta. Now, Brother, the coast is clear, and we have the Garden to our selves, Do you remember how you threatened me? but that's all one. How good soever the opportunity may be, so long as we two resolve to be vertuous.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: Speak for your self, Sister, for I am wickedly inclin'd. Yet, I confess, I have some remorse, when I consider you are in Religion.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: We should do very well to consider that, both of us; for, indeed, What should young people do, but think of Goodness and Religion; especially when they love one another, and are alone too, Brother?

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: A curse on't, here comes my Lord, and Lucretia. We might have accomplish'd all, and been repenting by this time; yet who the Devil would have thought they should have come so soon?â€” Ahâ€” Sets his Teeth.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Who the Devil would have put it to the venture? This is alwayes the fault of you raw Pages: you that are too young, never use an opportunity; and we that are elder can seldome get one.â€” Ah! Sets her Teeth.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I believe, indeed, it troubled you to lose that Letter.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: So much, Madam, that I can never forgive my self that negligence.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Call it not so, 'twas but a casualty, though, I confess, the consequence is dangerous; and therefore have not both of us reason to defy Love, when we see a little Gallantry is able to produce so much mischief.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: aside. Now cannot I, for my heart, bring out one word against this Love.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come, you are mute, upon a Subject that is both easie and pleasant. A man in Love is so ridiculous a creatureâ€”

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Especially to those that are not.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: True; for to those that are, he cannot be so: they are like the Citizens of Bethlehem, who never find out one anothers Maddess, because they are all tainted. But for such antient Fops, as (with reverence) your Father is, What reason can they have to be in Love?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Nay, your old Fop's unpardonable, that's certainâ€” Butâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But What? Come, laugh at him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But, I consider, he is my Father, I can't laugh at him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But, if it were another, we should see how you would insult over him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ay, if it were anotherâ€” And yet I don't know neither, 'tis no part of good nature to insult: a man may be overtaken with a passion, or so, I know it by my self.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How, by your self? you are not in love, I hope?
Oh that he would confess first now! Aside.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: But, if I were, I should be loath to be laugh'd at.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Since you are not in Love, you may the better counsel me: What shall I do with this same troublesome Father of yours?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Any thing, but love him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But you know he has me at a Bay; my Letter is in his possession, and he may produce it to my ruine: therefore if I did allow him some little favour, to mollify himâ€”

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: How, Madam? would you allow him Favours? I can never consent to it: not the least look or smile; they are all too precious, though they were to save his life.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What, Not your Father? Oh that he wou'd confess he lov'd me first! Aside.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What have I done? I shall betray my self, and confess my love, to be laugh'd at, by this hard-hearted Woman. Aside. 'Tis true, Madam, I had forgot; he is, indeed, my Father, and therefore you may use him as kindly as you please.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He's insensible: now he inrages me. Aside. What if he proposes to Marry me? I am not yet profess'd, and 'twould be much to my advantage.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Marry you! I had rather dye a thousand deaths, than suffer it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: This begins to please me. Aside.
But, Why should you be so much my enemy?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Your enemy, Madam? Why, Do you desire it?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Perhaps I do,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Do it, Madam, since it pleases you so well.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But you had rather dye, than suffer it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: No, I have chang'd my mind: I'll live, and not be concern'd at it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Do you contradict your self so soon? Then know, Sir, I did
intend to do it; and I am glad you have given me advice so agreeable to my inclinations.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Heaven! that you should not find it out! I deliver'd your Letter on purpose to my Father, and 'twas my business, now, to come and mediate for him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pray, then, carry him the news of his good success.
Adieu, sweet Prince.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Adieu, dear Madam.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: Hey day! What will this come to? they have cozen'd one another into a quarrel; just like friends in Fencing, a chance thrust comes, and then they fall to't in earnest.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You and I, Brother, shall never meet upon even termes, if this be not piec'd. Faces about, Madam, turn quickly to your Man, or by all that's virtuous, I'll call the Abbess.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: I must not be so bold with you, Sir; but, if you please, you may turn towards the Lady, and I suppose you would be glad I durst speak to you with more authority, to save the credit of your willingness.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well, I'll shew her I dare stay, if it be but to confront her Malice.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I am sure I have done nothing to be asham'd of, that I should need to run away.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: Pray give me leave, Sir, to ask you but one question; Why were you so unwilling that she should be Marry'd to your Father?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Because then, her Friendship must wholly cease.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: But, you may have her Friendship, when she is Marry'd to him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What, when another had enjoy'd her?

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: Victoria, Victoria, he loves you, Madam; let him deny it if he can.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Fie, fie, love me, Ascanio! I hope he would not forswear himself, when he has rail'd so much against it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I hope I may love your mind, Madam; I may Love Spiritually.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: That's enough, that's enough: let him love the mind without the body if he can.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p:
Ay, ay, when the love is once come so far, that Spiritual
Mind will never leave pulling, and pulling, till it has drawn the beastly body after it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well, Madam, since I must confess it, (though I expect to be laugh'd at, after my railing against Love) I do love you all over, both Soul and Body.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, What a Tygress have you provok'd! you may see she takes it to the death that you have made this declaration.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I thought where all her anger was: Why do you not raile, Madam? Why do you not banish him? the Prince expects it; he has dealt honestly, he has told you his Mind, and you make your worst on't.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Because he does expect it, I am resolv'd I'll neither satisfie him nor you; I will neither raile nor laugh: let him make his worst of that, now.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If I understand you right, Madam, I am happy beyond either my deserts or expectation.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You may give my words what interpretation you please, Sir, I shall not envy you their meaning in the kindest sence. But we are near the Jessamine-walk, there we may talk with greater freedom, because 'tis farther from the House.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I wait you, Madam. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE. V.
div.stage: Aurelian with a dark Lanthorn, Camillo and Benito.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: So, we are safe got over into the Nunnery-Garden; for what's to come, trust Love and Fortune.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: This must needs be the walk she mention'd; yet, to be sure, I'll hold the Lanthorn while you read the Ticket.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: reads. I prepar'd this Ticket, hoping to see you in the Chappel: come this evening over the Garden-wall, on the right hand, next the Tiber.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: (We are right, I see.)

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Bring only your discreet Benito with you, and I will meet you, attended by my faithful Beatrix. Violetta.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Discreet Benito! Did you hear that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Mortifie thy self for that vain thought; and, without enquiring into the mystery of these words, which I assure thee were not meant to thee, plant thy self by that Ladder without motion, to secure our retreat; and be sure to make no noise.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: But, Sir, in case thatâ€”

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Honest Benito, no more questions: Basta is the word. Remember, thou art only taken with us, because thou hast a certain evil Daemon who conducts thy actions, and would have been sure, by some damn'd accident or other, to have brought thee hither to disturb us.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I hear whispering not far from us, and I think 'tis Violetta's voice.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: to Benito. Retire to your Post; avoid, good Sathan.

div.stage: Enter Laura with a dark Lanthorn hid, and Violetta.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Ours is the honour of the Field, Madam; we are here before you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Softly, dear friend, I think I hear some walking in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Rather, let us take this opportunity for your escape from hence; all things are here in readiness.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: This is the second time we e're have met; let us discourse, and know each other better first: that's the way to make sure of some love before-hand; for, as the world goes, we know not how little we may have when we are Marry'd.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Losses of opportunity are fatal, in war, you know, and Love's a kind of warfare.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I shall keep you yet a while from close fighting.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: But, Do you know what an hour in Love is worth? 'Tis more precious than an Age of ordinary life; 'tis the very Quintesence and Extract of it.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I do not like your Chymical preparation of love; yours is all Spirit, and will fly too soon: I must see it fix'd, before I trust you. But we are near the Arbor; now our out guards are set, let us retire a little, if you please; there we may talk more freely.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: to Laura. My Ladies Woman, methinks you are very reserv'd to night: pray advance into the Lists; though I have seen your countenance by day, I can endure to hear you talk by night. Be cunning, and set your wit to show which is your best commodity: it will help the better to put off that drug, your Face.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: The coursest ware will serve such customers as you are: let it suffice, Mr. Servingman, that I have seen you too. Your face is the original of the ugliest Vizors about Town; and for wit, I would advise you to speak reverently of it, as a thing you are never like to understand.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Sure, Beatrix, you came lately from looking in your Glass, and that has given you a bad opinion of all faces. But since when am I become so notorious a fool?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Since yesterday; for t'other night you talk'd like a man of sence: I think your wit comes to you, as the sight of Owles does, only in the dark.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why, When did you discourse by day with me?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: You have a short memory. This afternoon, in the great street. Do you not remember when you talk'd with Laura?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But what was that to Beatrix?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: aside. ' Slife, I had forgot that I am Beatrix.
But, pray, When did you find me out to be so ugly?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: This afternoon, in the Chappel.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: That cannot be, for I well remember you were not there, Benito: I saw none but Camillo, and his friend the handsome stranger.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: aside. Curse on't, I have betray'd my self.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I find you are an Impostor; you are not the same Benito: your language has nothing of the Serving-man.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And yours, methinks, has not much of the Waiting-woman.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: My Lady is abus'd, and betray'd by you: but I am resolv'd
I'll discover who you are. Holds out a Lanthorn to him.
How? the Stranger!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, if you are good at that, I'll match you there too. Holds out his Lanthorn. O prodigy! Is Beatrix turn'd to Laura?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Now the question is, which of us two is the greatest cheat?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: That's hardly to be try'd, at so short warning: Let's Marry one another, and then, twenty to one, in a Twelve Moneth we shall know.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Marry! Are you at that so soon, Signior? Benito and Beatrix, I confess, had some acquaintance; but Aurelian and Laura are meer strangers.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: That ground I have gotten as Benito, I am resolv'd I'll keep as Aurelian. If you will take State upon you, I have treated you with Ceremony already; for I have woo'd you by Proxy.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: But you would not be contented to bed me so; or give me leave to put the Sword betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Yes, upon condition you'll remove it.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Pray let our Friends be judge of it; if you please, we'll find 'em in the Arbor.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Content; I am then sure of the Verdict, because the Jury is brib'd already. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: Benito meeting Frederick, Ascanio, Lucreria and Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Knowing my own merits, as I do, 'tis not impossible but some of these Harlotry Nuns may love me: Oh, here's my Master! now if I could but put this into civil termes, so as to ask his leave, and not displease himâ€”

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: I hear one talking, Sir, just by us.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I am stoln from my post, Sir, but for one minute only, to demand permission of you, since it is not in our Articles, that if any of these Nuns should cast an eye or soâ€”

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: 'Slife, we are betray'd; but I'll make this Rascal sure.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Help, Murder, Murder. Runs off.

div.stage: Enter Aurelian and Camillo; Laura and Violetta after them.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: That was Benito's voice: we are ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Oh, here they are; we must make our way.

div.stage: Aur. and the Prince make a Pass or two confusedly, and fight off the Stage. The Women Schreek.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: Never fear, Ladies. Come on, Sir; I am your Man.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: stepping back. This is the Prince's Page, I know his voice, Ascanio?

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: Signior Camillo!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: If the Prince be here, 'tis Aurelian is engag'd with him. Let us run in quickly, and prevent the mischief.

div.stage: All go off. A little Clashing within.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: to Aur. I hope you are not wounded.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No, Sir; but infinitely griev'd thatâ€”

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: No more; 'twas a mistake: but which way can we escape, the Abbess is coming, I see the Lights.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You cannot go by the Gate then. Ah me, unfortunate!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: But over the Wall you may: we have a Ladder ready. Adieu, Ladies. Curse on this ill luck, where we had just perswaded e'm to go with us!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Farewell, sweet Lucretia.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Goodnight, Aurelian.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I, it might have prov'd a good one: Faith, shall I stay, yet, and make it one, in spite of the Abbess, and all her Works?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: The Abbess is just here; you will be caught
In the Spiritual Trap, if you should tarry.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: That will be time enough when we two Marry.

div.head: ACT. V. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: BY this, then, it appears you all are guilty;
Only your ignorance of each others crimes
Caus'd first that tumult, and this discovery.
Good Heavens, that I should live to see this day!
Methinks these Holy Walls, the Cells, the Cloysters,
Should all have strook a secret horror on you:
And when, with unchast thoughts,
You trod these lonely walks, you should have look'd
The venerable Ghost of our first Foundress
Should with spread arms have met you in her Shroud,
And frighted you from Sin.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Alass, you need not aggravate our crimes,
We know them to be great beyond excuse,
And have no hope, but only from your mercy.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Love is, indeed, no plea within these Walls;
But, since we brought it hither, and were forc'd,
Not led by our own choice, to this strict lifeâ€”

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Too hard for our soft youth, and bands of love,
Which we before had knit.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: â€” Pity your blood,
Which runs within our veins, and since Heaven puts it
In your sole power to ruine or to save,
Protect us from the sordid avarice
Of our domestick Tyrant, who deserves not
That we should call him Uncle, or you Brother.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: If, as I might, with Justice I should punish,
No penance could be rigorous enough;
But I am willing to be more indulgent.
None of you are Profess'd: and since I see
You are not fit for higher happiness,
You may have what you think the world can give you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Let us adore you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: â€” You, Lucretia,
I shall advise within.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: â€” But for us, Madam?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: For you, dear Neeces, I have long consider'd
The injuries you suffer from my Brother,
And I rejoyce it is in me to help you:
I will endeavour, from this very hour,
To put you both into your Lovers hands,
Who, by your own confession, have deserv'd you;
But so as (though 'tis done by my connivance)
It shall not seem to be with my consent.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: You do an act of noble charity,
And may just heaven reward it.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Oh, you're a faithful Portress of a Cloyster.
What is't you whisper to Lucretia?
On your Obedience tell me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: â€” Since you must know, Madam,
I have receiv'd a Courtship from the Prince
Of Mantoua. The rest Hippolita may speak.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: His Page Ascanio is at the grate,
To know from him, how you had scap'd this danger;
And brings with him those Habitsâ€”

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I find that here has been a long commerce.
What Habits?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I blush to tell you, Madam. They were Masking Habits, in which we went abroad.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: O strange Impiety! Well, I conclude
You are no longer for Religious cloathing:
You would infect our Order.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: kneeling. Madam, you promis'd us forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I have done; for 'tis indeed too late to chide.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
With Ascanio, there are two Gentlemen; Aurelian and Camillo
I think they call themselves, who came to me, recommended from the Prince, and desir'd to speak with Laura and Violetta.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I think they are your Lovers, Neeces.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Madam, they are.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: But, for fear of discovery from your Unckle Mario, whose House you know, joyns to the Monastery, are both in Masquerade.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: to Laura and Violetta. This opportunity must not be lost.
You two shall take the Masking-habits instantly,
And, in them, scape your jealous Unckle's eyes.
When you are happy, make me so, by hearing your success.

div.stage: Kisses them. Exeunt Lau. and Vio.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A sudden thought is sprung within my mind,
Which, by the same indulgence you have shown,
May make me happy too. I have not time
To tell you now, for fear I lose this opportunity.
When I return from speaking with Ascanio,
I shall declare the secrets of my Love,
And crave your farther help.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: In all that virtue will permit you shall not fail to find it.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Madam, the foolish Fellow whom we took grows troublesome; What shall we do with him?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Send for the Magistrate; he must be punish'dâ€”
Yet hold; that would betray the other secret.
Let him be strait turn'd out, on this Condition,
That he presume not ever to disclose
He was within these walls. I'll speak with him:
Come, and attend me to him. Exit Sophronia.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You fit to be an Abbess? We that live out of the World, should at least have the common sence of those that live farr from Town; if a Pedler comes by 'em once a year, they will not let him go without providing themselves with what they want.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Aurelian, Camillo, Laura, Violetta: all in Masking habits.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: This generosity of the Abbess is never to be forgot; and it is the more to be esteem'd because it was the less to be expected.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: At length, my Camillo, I see my self safe within your Armes; and yet, methinks, I can never be enough secure of you: for, now I have nothing else to fear, I am afraid of you; I fear your constancy: they say possession is so dangerous to Lovers, that more of them die of Surfeits than of Fasting.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: You'll be rambling too, Aurelian, I do not doubt it, if I would let you; but I'll take care to be as little a Wife, and as much a Mistriss to you, as is possible: I'll be sure to be alwayes pleasant, and never suffer you to be cloy'd.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You are certainly in the right: pleasantness of humour makes a Wife last in the sweet meat, when it will no longer in the Fruit. But pray let's make haste to the next honest Priest, that can say Grace to us, and take our appetites while they are coming.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: That way leads to the Austin-Fryers, there lives a Father of my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I have heard of him; he has a mighty stroke at Matrimonies, and mumbles 'em over as fast, as if he were teaching us to forget 'em all the while.

div.stage: Enter Benito, and over-hears the last speech.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Cappari; that's the voice of Madam Laura. Now, Benito, is the time to repair the lost honour of thy wit, and to blot out the last adventure of the Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: That way I hear company; let's go about by this other street, and shun 'em.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: That voice I know too; 'tis the younger Sister, Violetta's. Now have these two most treacherously convey'd themselves out of the Nunnery, for my Master and Camillo, and given up their persons to those lewd Rascals in Masquerade; but I'll prevent 'em. Help there, Thieves and Ravishers, villanous Maskers, stop Robbers, stop Ravishers.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: We are pursu'd that way, let's take this street.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Save your selves, and leave us.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: We'll rather dye than leave you.

div.stage: Enter at several doors Duke of Mantoua and Guards, and Don Mario and Servants, with Torches.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: So, now the way is shut up on both sides. We'll dye merrily however:â€” have at the fairest.

div.stage: Aurelian and Camillo fall upon the Dukes Guards, and are seiz'd behind by Mario 's Servants. At the drawing of Swords, Benito runs off.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Are these insolencies usually committed in Rome by night? it has the fame of a well-govern'd City; and methinks, Don Mario, it does somewhat reflect on you to suffer these Disorders.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: They are not to be hinder'd in the Carnival: you see, Sir, they have assum'd the Priviledge of Maskers.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: to Au. If my Unckle know us, we are ruin'd; therefore be sure you do not speak.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How then can we be satisfy'd this was not a device of Masking, rather than a design of Ravishing?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Their accuser is fled, I saw him run at the beginning of the scuffle; but I'll examine the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Now we are lost.

div.stage: Duke coming near Laura takes notice of her Habit.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: aside. 'Tis the same, 'tis the same; I know Lucretia by her Habit: I'm sure I am not mistaken. Now, Sir, you may cease your examination, I know the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: to Cam. How the Devil does he know 'em?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: 'Tis alike to us; they are lost both wayes.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: taking Laura aside. Madam, you may confess your self to me. Whatever your design was in leaving the Nunnery, your reputation shall be safe. I'll not discover you, provided you grant me the happiness I last requested.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I know not, Sir, how you could possibly come to know me, or of my design in quitting the Nunnery; but this I know, that my Sister and my self are both unfortunate, except your Highness be pleas'd to protect us from our Unckle; at least, not to discover us.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: His Holiness your Unckle, shall never be acquainted with your flight, on Condition you will wholly renounce my Son, and give your self to me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Alass, Sir, For whom do you mistake me?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I mistake you not, Madam: I know you for Lucretia. You forget that your Disguise betrayes you.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Then, Sir, I perceive I must disabuse you: if you please to withdraw a little, that I may not be seen by others, I will pull off my Mask, and discover to you that Lucretia and I have no resemblance, but only in our misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: 'Tis in vain, Madam, this dissembling: I protest if you pull off your Mask, I will hide my Face, and not look upon you, to convince you that I know you.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: So, now the fray is over, a man may appear again with safety. Oh, the Rogues are caught I see, and the Damsels deliver'd. This was the effect of my valour at the second hand.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Look, look, Camillo, it was my perpetual Fool that caus'd all this, and now he stands yonder, laughing at his mischief, as the Devil is pictur'd, grinning behind the Witch upon the Gallows.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: to Mario. I see, Sir, you have got your Women, and I am glad on't: I took 'em just flying from the Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: to Lau. You see that Fellow knows you too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Were these Women flying from a Nunnery?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: These Women? Hey day! then, it seems, you do not know they are your Neeces.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: His Neeces, say you? Take heed, Fellow, you shall be punish'd severely if you mistake.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Speak to Benito in time, Aurelian.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: The Devil's in him, he's running down-hill full speed, and there is no stopping him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My Neeces?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Your Neeces? Why, Do you doubt it? I praise Heaven I never met but with two half-wits in my life, and my Master's one of'em; I will not name the other, at this time.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I say they are not they.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I am sure they are Laura and Violetta, and that those two Rogues were running away with 'em, and that I believe with their consent.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Sister, 'Tis in vain to deny our selves; you see our ill fortune pursues us unavoidably. Turning up her Masque. Yes, Sir, we are Laura and Violetta, whom you have made unhappy by your Tyranny.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: turning up her Mask. And these two Gentlemen are no Ravishers, butâ€”

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: How, no Ravishers? yes, to my knowledge, they areâ€” As he speaks, Aurelian pulls off his Mask. no Ravishers, as Madam Laura was saying; but two as honest Gentlemen as e're broke bread: My own dear Master, and so forth!

div.stage: Runs to Aurelian, who thrusts him back.
Enter Valerio, and whispers the Duke, giving him a Paper, which he reads, and seemes pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Aurelian and Camillo! I'll see you in safe custody, and,
for, these Fugitives, go, carry 'em to my Sister, and desire her to have a better care of her Kinswomen.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: We shall live yet to make you refund our Portions. Farewell Camillo; comfort your self; remember there's but a Wall betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: And I'll cut through that Wall with Vineger, but I'll come to you, Aurelian.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I'll cut through the Grates with Aqua-sortis, but I'll meet you. Think of these things, and despair and dye, old Gentleman.

div.stage: Aurelian and Camillo are carry'd off on one side, and Laura and Violetta on the other.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: All things go cross to men of sence: would I had been born with the brains of a Shop-keeper, that I might have thriven without knowing why I did so. Now must I follow my Master to the Prison, and, like an ignorant Customer that comes to buy, must offer him my back-side, tell him I trust to his honesty, and desire him to please himself, and so be satisfy'd. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: to Valerio. I am overjoy'd, I'll see her immediately: now my business with Don Mario is at an end, I need not desire his company to introduce me to the Abbess, this Assignation from Lucretia shows me a nearer way. Noble Don Mario, it was my business when this accident happen'd in the street to have made you a visit; but now I am prevented by an occasion which calls me another way.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I receive the intention of that honour as the greatest happiness that cou'd befall me: in the mean time, if my attendanceâ€”

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: By no means, Sir, I must of necessity go in private, and therefore, if you please, you shall omit the ceremony.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: A happy even to your Highness. Now will I go to my Sister the Abbess, before I sleep, and desire her to take more care of her Flock, or, for all our Relation, I shall make complaint, and indeavour to ease her of her charge. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: So, now we are alone, What said Lucretia?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: When first I press'd her to this Assignation,
She spoke like one in doubt what she should do;
She demur'd much upon the decency of it,
And somewhat too she seem'd to urge, of her
Engagement to the Prince: in short, Sir,
I perceiv'd her wavering; and clos'd with the opportunity.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: O, when women are once irresolute, betwixt the former love and the new one, they are sure to come over to the latter: the wind, their nearest likeness, seldome chops about to return into the old corner.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: In conclusion, she consented to the interview, and for the rest, I urg'd it not, for I suppose she will hear reason sooner from your mouth than mine.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Her Letter is of the same tenor with her Discourse; full of doubts and doubles, like a hunted Hare when she's near tyr'd. The Garden, you say, is the place appointed?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It is, Sir; and the next half hour the time: but, Sir, I fear the Prince your Son will never bear the loss of her with patience.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter; let the young Gallant storm to night, to morrow he departs from Rome.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That, Sir, will be severe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: He has already receiv'd my commands to travel into Germany: I know it stung him to the quick; but he's too dangerous a Rival: the Souldiers love him too; when he's absent they will respect me more. Exeunt Guards.
sp.l: But I defer my happiness too long; dismiss my Guards there.
The pleasures of old age brook no delay:
Seldome they come, and soon they fly away. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis true, he is my Father; but when Nature
Is dead in him, Why should it live in me?
What have I done, that I am banish'd Rome,
The Worlds delight, and my Souls joy Lucretia,
And sent to reel with midnight Beasts in Almain?
I cannot, will not bear it.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: I'm sure you need not, Sir: the Army is all yours; they wish a youthful Monarch, and will resent your injuries.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Heaven forbid it. And yet I cannot lose Lucretia.
There's something I would do, and yet would shun
The ill that must attend it.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: You must resolve, for the time presses. She told me, this hour, she had sent for your Father: what she means I know not, for she seem'd doubtful, and would not tell me her intention.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If she be false;â€” yet, Why should I suspect her? yet, Why should I not? she's a Woman; that includes ambition, and inconstancy: then, she's tempted high: 'twere unreasonable to expect she should be faithful: well, something I have resolv'd and will about it instantly: and if my Friends prove faithful I shall prevent the worst.
Aurelian and Camillo? How came you thus attended?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: You may guess at the occasion, Sir; pursuing the adventure which brought us to meet you in the Garden, we were taken by Don Mario.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And, as the Devil would have it, when both we and our Mistresses were in expectation of a more pleasant lodging.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Faith, that's very hard, when a man has charg'd and prim'd, and taken aim, to be hinder'd of his shootâ€” Souldiers, release these Gentlemen; I'll answer it.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sir, we dare not disobey our Orders.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I'll stand betwixt you and danger. In the mean time take this, as an acknowledgment of the kindness you do me.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ay, marry, there's Rhetorique in Gold: Who can deny these arguments? Sir, you may dispose of our prisoners as you please; we'll use your name if we are call'd in question.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Do so. Good-night good Souldiers. Exeunt Souldiers. Now, Gentlemen, no thanks, you'll find occasion instantly to reimburse me of my kindness.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Nothing but want of liberty could have hinder'd us from serving you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Meet me, within this half hour, at our Monastery; and if, in the mean time, you can pick up a dozen of good Fellows, who dare venture their lives bravely, bring them with you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I hope the Cause is bad too, otherwise we shall not deserve your thanks: may it be for demolishing that cursed Monastery.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Come, Ascanio, follow me. Exeunt severally.

div.head: SCENE IV.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: In making this appointment,
I go too far, for one of my profession;
But I have a divining Soul within me,
Which tells me, trust repos'd in noble natures
Obliges them the more.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I come to be commanded, not to govern,
Those few soft words you sent me, have quite alter'd
My rugged nature; if it still be violent,
'Tis only fierce and eager to obey you,
Like some impetuous flood, which Master'd once,
With double force bends backward.
The place of Treaty shows you strongest here;
For still the vanquish'd sues for peace abroad,
While the proud Victor makes his termes at home.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That peace, I see, will not be hard to make
When either side shows confidence of noble dealing
From the other.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And this, sure, is our case, since both are met alone.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Tis mine, Sir, more than yours.
To meet you single, shows I trust your virtue;
But you appear distrustful of my Love.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You wrong me much, I am not.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Excuse me, Sir, you keep a curb upon me:
You awe me with a Letter, which you hold
As Hostage of my Love; and Hostages
Are ne'r requir'd but from suspected Faith.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: We are not yet in termes of perfect peace;
When e're you please to seal the Articles,
Your pledge shall be restor'd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That were the way to keep us still at distance;
For what we fear, we cannot truly love.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But how can I be then secure, that when
Your fear is o're your love will still continue?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Make tryal of my gratitude; you'll find
I can acknowledge kindness.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But that were to forego the faster hold
To take a loose, and weaker.
Would you not judge him mad who held a Lion
In chains of Steel, and chang'd e'm for a twine?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But love is soft,
Not of the Lion's nature, but the Dove's;
An Iron chain would hang too heavy on a tender neck.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Since on one side there must be confidence,
Why may not I expect, as well as you,
To have it plac'd in me? Repose your trust
Upon my Royal word.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: As 'tis the priviledge of womankind
That men should court our Love,
And make the first advances; so it follows
That you should first oblige; for 'tis our weakness
Gives us more cause of fear, and therefore you,
Who are the stronger Sex, should first secure it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But, Madam, as you talk of fear from me,
I may as well suspect design from you,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Designâ–ª of giving you my Love more freely,
Of making you a Title to my heart,
Where you by force would reign.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O that I could believe you! but your words
Are not enough disorder'd for true love;
They are not plain, and hearty, as are mine;
But full of art, and close insinuation:
You promise all, but give me not one proof
Of love before; not the least earnest of it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And, What is then this midnight conversation?
These silent hours divided from my sleep?
Nay, more; stoln from my Prayers with Sacriledge,
And here transfer'd to you? This guilty hand,
Which should be us'd in dropping holy Beads,
But now, bequeath'd to yours? This heaving heart,
Which only should be throbing for my sins,
But which now beats uneven time for you?
These are my arts! and these are my designs!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I love you more, Lucretia, than my Soul;
Nay, than yours too, for I would venture both
That I might now enjoy you; and if what
You ask me did not make me fear to lose you,
Though it were even my life, you should not be deny'd it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then I will ask no more.
Keep my Letter, to upbraid me with it;
To Say, when I am sully'd with your Lust,
And fit to be forsaken, Go, Lucretia,
To your first love; for this, for this, I leave you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Oh, Madam, never think that day can come!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It must, it will, I read it in your looks;
You will betray me when I'm once engag'd.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: If not my Faith, your Beauty will secure you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My Beauty is a Flower upon the stalk,
Goodly to see; but, gather'd for the scent,
And once with eagerness press'd to your nostrils,
The sweet's drawn out, 'tis thrown with scorn away.
But I am glad I find you out so soon:
I simply lov'd, and meant (with shame I own it)
To trust my Virgin-honour in your hands;
I ask'd not wealth, for hire; and, but by chance,
(I wonder that I thought on't) beg'd one tryal,
And, but for form, to have pretence to yield,
And that you have deny'd me. Farewell: I could
Have lov'd you, and yet, perhaps, Iâ€”

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O speak, speak out, and do not drown that word,
It seem'd as if it would have been a kind one,
And yours are much too precious to be lost.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Perhapsâ€” I cannot yet leave loving you.
There 'twas. But I recall'd it in my mind,
And made it false before I gave it Ayr.
Once more, farewellâ€” I wonnot;
Now I can say I wonnot, wonnot love youâ–ª Going.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You shall; and this shall be the Seal of my affection.
There, take it, my Lucretia; I give it with more joy,
Than I with grief receiv'd it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Good night; I'll thank you for't some other time.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You'll not abuse my love?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No; but secure my Honour.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I'll force it from your hands. Lucretia runs.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Help, help, or I am ravish'd; help, for heavens sake.
sp.stage: Hippolita, Laura, and Violetta within, in several places.
sp.l: Within. Help, help Lucretia; they bear away Lucretia by force.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I think there is a Devil in every corner.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, the design was lay'd on purpose for you, and all the women plac'd to cry. Make haste away; avoid the shame for heavens sake.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: going. O, I could fire this Monastery!

div.stage: (Frederick entring speaks as to some behind him)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Pain of your lives, let none of you presume to enter but my self.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
My Son! O, I could burst with spite, and dye with shame, to be thus apprehended! this is the baseness and cowardise of guilt:
an Army now were not so dreadful to me as that Son, o're whom the right of Nature gives me power.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Sir, I am comeâ€”

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: To laugh at first, and then to blaze abroad
The weakness, and the follies of your Father.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, he has Men in Armes attending him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I know my doom then. You have taken a popular occasion; I am now a ravisher of chastity, fit to be made prisoner first, and then depos'd.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You will not hear me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No, I confess I have deserv'd my fate;
For, What had these gray haires to do with Love?
Or, if th' unseemly folly would possess me,
Why should I choose to make my Son my Rival:

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Sir, you may add you banish'd me from Rome,
And from the light of it, Lucretia's eyes.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Nay, if thou aggravat'st my crimes, thou giv'st
Me right to justify'em: thou doubly art my slave,
Both Son and Subject. I can do thee no wrong,
Nor hast thou right t'arraign or punish me:
But thou inquir'st into thy Fathers years;
Thy swift ambition could not stay my death,
But must ride post to Empire. Lead me now:
Thy crimes have made me guiltless to my self,
And given me face to bear the publick scorn.
You have a guard without?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I have some friends.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Speak plainly your intent.
I love not a sophisticated truth,
With an allay of lye in't.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: kneeling. This is not, Sir, the posture of a Rebel,
But of a suppliant, if the Name of Son
Be too much honour to me.
What first I purpos'd, I scarce know my self.
Love, Anger, and Revenge then rowl'd within me,
And yet, ev'n then, I was not hurry'd farther
Than to preserve my own.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: â€” Your own! What mean you?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: My Love, and my Lucretia; which I thought
In my then boyling passion, you pursu'd
With some injustice, and much violence;
This led me to repell that force by force.
'Twas easie to surprize you, when I knew
Of your intended visit.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: â€” Thank my folly.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: But reason now has reassum'd its place,
And makes me see how black a crime it is
To use a force upon my Prince and Father.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You give me hope you will resign Lucretia.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ah no: I never can resign her to you;
But, Sir, I can my life: which, on my knees,
I tender, as th'attoning Sacrifice.
Or if your hand (because you are a Father)
Be loath to take away that life you gave,
I will redeem your crime, by making it
My own: So you shall still be innocent, and I
Dye bless'd, and unindebted for my being.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: embracing him. O Frederick, you are too much a Son,
And I too little am a Father: You,
And you alone, have merited Lucretia.
'Tis now my only grief,
I can do nothing to requite this virtue;
For to restore her to you
Is not an act of generosity,
But a scant, niggard Justice; yet I love her
So much, that even this little which I do
Is like the bounty of an Usurer;
High to be priz'd from me,
Because 'tis drawn from such a wretched mind.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: kissing his hands. You give me now a second, better life;
But, that the gift may be more easie to you,
Consider, Sir, Lucretia did not Love you:
I fear to say ne'r would.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You do well, to help me to o'recome that difficulty:
I'll weigh that, too, hereafter. For a love,
So violent as mine, will ask long time,
And much of reason, to effect the cure.
My present care shall be to make you happy;
For that will make my wish impossible,
And then the remedies will be more easie.

div.stage: Enter Sophronia, Lucretia, Violetta, Laura, Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I have, with joy, o'reheard this happy change,
And come, with blessings, to applaud your conquest,
Over the greatest of Mankind, your self.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I hope 'twill be a full, and lasting one.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: kneeling. Thus, let me kneel, and pay my thanks and duty.
Both to my Prince, and Father?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Rise, rise, too charming Maid; for yet I cannot
Call you Daughter: that first name, Lucretia,
Hangs on my lips, and would be still pronounc'd.
Look not too kindly on me; one sweet glance,
Perhaps, would ruine both: therefore, I'll go
And try to get new strength to bear your eyes.
Till then, Farewell. Be sure you love my Frederick,
And do not hate his Father. Exeunt Duke and Valerio.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: at the door. Now, friends, you may appear.
Your pardon. Madam, that we thus intrude
On holy ground: your self best know it could not
Be avoided, and it shall be my care it be excus'd.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Though Soveraign Princes bear a priviledge,
Of entring when they please within our walls,
In others, 'tis a crime past dispensation:
And therefore, to avoid a publick scandal,
Be pleas'd, Sir, to retire, and quit this Garden.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: We shall obey you, Madam: But, that we may do it with less regret, we hope you will give these Ladies leave to accompany us.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: They shall.
And Neeces, for my self, I only ask you
To justify my conduct to the world,
That none may think I have betray'd a trust,
But freed you from a Tyranny.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Our duty binds us to acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And our gratitude, to witness it.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: With a holy, and lasting remembrance of your favour.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And it shall be my care, either by reason to bend your Unckle's will, or, by my Father's interest, to force your Dowry from his hands.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: to Aur. Pray, Sir, let us make haste over these Walls again, these Gardens are unlucky to me: I have lost my reputation of Musick in the one of 'em, and of wit in the other.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: to Lau. Now, Laura, you may take your choice betwixt the two Benito's, and consider whether you had rather he should Serenade you in the Garden, or I in Bed to night.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: You may be sure I shall give Sentence for Benito; for, the effect of your Serenading would be to make me pay the Musick nine Moneths hence.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: to Asca. You see, Brother, here's a General Jayle-delivery: there has been a great deal of bustle and disturbance in the Cloyster to night; enough to distract a Soul which is given up, like me, to contemplation: and therefore, if you think fit, I could een be content to retire, with you, into the World; and, by way of Penance, to Marry you; which, as Husbands and Wives go now, is a greater Mortification than a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.p: No, Sister, if you love me, keep to your Monastery: I'll come now and then to the Grate and beg you a Recreation. But I know my self so well, that, if I had you one twelve Moneth in the world, I should run my self into a Cloyster, to be rid of you.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Neeces, once more farewell. Adieu, Lucretia:
My wishes and my prayers attend you all.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: to Fred. I am so fearful,
That, though I gladly run to your embraces,
Yet, ventring in the World a second time,
Methinks I put to Sea in a rough storm,
With shipwracks round about me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: My Dear, be kinder to your self, and me,
And let not fear fright back our coming joyes;
For we, at length, stand reconcil'd to fare:
And now to fear, when to such bliss we move,
Were not to doubt our Fortune, but our Love.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: SOme have expected from our Bills to day
To find a Satyre in our Poet's Play.
The Zealous Rout from Coleman-street did run,
To see the Story of the Fryer and Nun.
Or Tales, yet more Ridiculous to hear,
Vouch'd by their Vicar of Ten pounds a year;
Of Nuns, who did against Temptation Pray,
And Discipline laid on the Pleasant way:
Or that to please the Malice of the Town,
Our Poet should in some close Cell have shown
Some Sister, Playing at Content alone:
This they did hope; the other side did fear,
And both you see alike are Couzen'd here.
Some thought the Title of our Play to blame,
They lik'd the thing, but yet abhor'd the Name:
Like Modest Puncks, who all you ask afford,
But, for the World, they would not name that word.
Yet, if you'll credit what I heard him say,
Our Poet meant no Scandal in his Play;
His Nuns are good which on the Stage are shown,
And, sure, behind our Scenes you'll look for none.
